div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: A drawing-room at the Hunters ’ , handsomely and artistically furnished . The woodwork and furniture are in the period of Louis XVI . The walls and furniture are covered with yellow brocade , and the curtains are of the same golden material . At the back are two large windows which give out on Fifth Avenue , opposite the Park , the trees of which are seen across the way . At Left is a double doorway , leading into the hall . At Right , opposite , is a door which leads to other rooms , and thence to other parts of the house . In the centre , at back , between the two windows , is the fireplace ; on the mantel are two vases and a clock in dark blue ormolu . There is a white and gold piano on the Right side of the room . The room suggests much wealth , and that it has been done by a professional decorator ; the personal note of taste is lacking .
It is four o'clock in the afternoon . The shades of the windows are drawn down . There are rows and rows of camp-chairs filling the entire room .

The curtain rises slowly . After a moment , JORDAN , the butler , and LEONARD , a footman , enter from the Left and begin to gather together and carry out the camp-chairs . They do this with very serious faces , and take great pains to step softly and to make no noise . They enter a second time for more chairs .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Whispers to LEONARD .When are they coming for the chairs ?

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Whispers back .To-night . Say , it was fine , was n't it !

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Grand !

div.stage: They go out with the chairs and immediately reënter for more . They are followed in this time by a lady 's maid , TOMPSON ; she is not a young woman . As she crosses the room she stoops and picks up a faded flower which has fallen from some emblem . She goes to the window at Right , and peeps out . She turns around and looks at the others . They all speak in subdued voices .

sp.speaker: TOMPSON
sp.p: Jordan , what do you think — can we raise the shades now ?

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Yes , of course — after they 've left the house it 's all over as far as we here are concerned .

div.stage: She raises both shades .

sp.speaker: TOMPSON
sp.p: Phew ! what an odor of flowers !

div.stage: She opens one of the windows a little .
MARIE , a young , pretty , French woman , enters from the Right .

sp.speaker: MARIE
sp.p: Will I help you ?

sp.speaker: TOMPSON
sp.p: Just with this table , thank you , Marie .They begin to rearrange the room , putting it in its normal condition . They replace the table and put back the ornaments upon it .Poor Mr. Hunter , and him so fond of mince pie . I shall never forget how that man ate mince pie .

div.stage: She sighs lugubriously and continues her labor with the room .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: I hope as how it 's not going to make any difference with us .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Pompously .Of course not ; was n't Mr. Hunter a millionnaire ?

sp.speaker: TOMPSON
sp.p: Some millionnaires I 've known turned out poor as Job 's turkey in their coffins !

sp.speaker: MARIE
sp.p: What you say ? You tink we shall ‘ ave some of madame 's or ze young ladies ’ dresses ?

sp.speaker: TOMPSON
sp.p: Hopefully .Perhaps .

lg.l: I ‘ ave already made my choice . I like ze pale pink of Mees
Jessie .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Sh ! I heard a carridge .

sp.speaker: TOMPSON
sp.p: Then they 're coming back .

div.stage: MARIE quickly goes out Right .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: To LEONARD , hurriedly , as he quickly goes out Left .Take them last two chairs !

div.stage: LEONARD , with the chairs , follows JORDAN out Left . TOMPSON hastily puts back a last arm-chair to its usual position in the room and goes out Right . MRS. HUNTER enters Left , followed by her three daughters , BLANCHE , JESSICA , and CLARA , and MASTER STERLING , who is a small , attractive child , five years of age . All are in the deepest conventional mourning , MRS. HUNTER in widow 's weeds and CLARA with a heavy , black chiffon veil ; the BOY is also dressed in conventional mourning . As soon as they enter , all four women lift their veils . MRS. HUNTER is a well-preserved woman , with a pretty , rather foolish , and somewhat querulous face . Her figure is the latest mode . BLANCHE STERLING , her oldest daughter , is her antithesis ,— a handsome , dignified woman , young , sincere , and showing , in her attitude to the others and in her own point of view , the warmth of a true , evenly-balanced nature . JESSICA is a typical second child ,— nice , good , self-effacing , sympathetic , unspoiled . CLARA is her opposite ,— spoiled , petulant , pretty , pert , and selfish .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: With a long sigh .Oh , I am so glad to be back home and the whole thing over without a hitch !

div.stage: She sinks with a great sigh of relief into a big chair .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Takes her son to MRS. HUNTER .Kiss grandmother good-by , and then Leonard will take you home .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Good-by , dear . Be a good boy . Do n't eat too much candy .

div.stage: Kisses him carelessly .

sp.speaker: MASTER STERLING
sp.p: Good-by .Runs towards the door Left , shouting happily .Leonard ! Leonard !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Tearfully .My dears , it was a great success ! Everybody was there !

div.stage: The three younger women stand and look about the room , as if it were strange to them — as if it were empty . There is a moment 's silence .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Tenderly .Mother , why do n't you take off your bonnet ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Take it off for me ; it will be a great relief .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Help me , Jess .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Irritably .Yes , do something , Jessie . You 've mortified me terribly to-day ! That child has n't shed a tear . People 'll think you did n't love your father .The two are taking off MRS. HUNTER 'S bonnet . MRS. HUNTER waits for an answer from JESSICA ; none comes .I never saw any one so heartless !Tearful again .And her father adored her . She was one of the things we quarrelled most about !

div.stage: Over MRS. HUNTER 'S head BLANCHE exchanges a sympathetic look with JESSICA to show she understands .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I 'm sure I 've cried enough . I 've cried buckets .

div.stage: She goes to MRS. HUNTER as BLANCHE and JESSICA take away the bonnet and veil and put them on the piano .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Kissing Clara .Yes , dear , you are your mother 's own child . And you lose the most by it , too .

div.stage: Leaning against the side of her mother 's chair , with one arm about her mother .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Yes , indeed , instead of coming out next month , and having a perfectly lovely winter , I 'll have to mope the whole season , and , if I do n't look out , be a wallflower without ever having been a bud !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Half amused but feeling CLARA 'S remark is perhaps not quite the right thing .Sh —

div.stage: During CLARA 'S speech above , BLANCHE has taken JESSICA in her arms a moment and kissed her tenderly , slowly . They rejoin MRS. HUNTER , BLANCHE wiping her eyes , JESSICA still tearless .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: And think of all the clothes we brought home from Paris last month !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: My dear , do n't think of clothes — think of your poor father ! That street dress of mine will dye very well , and we 'll give the rest to your aunt and cousins .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Mother , do n't you want to go upstairs ?

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Sincerely moved .Yes , I hate this room now .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Rising .Hate this room ! When we 've just had it done ! Louis Kinge !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Louis Quinze , dear ! She means the associations now , mother .

lg.l: Oh , yes , but that 's weak and foolish , Jessie . No ,
Blanche —
— I 'm too exhausted to move . Ring for tea .

div.stage: BLANCHE rings the bell beside the mantel .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Crossing to piano , forgets and starts to play a music-hall song , but MRS. HUNTER stops her .Oh , yes , tea ! I 'm starved !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Clara , darling ! As if you could be hungry at such a time !

div.stage: JORDAN enters Left .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Tea , Jordan .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Yes , madam .

div.stage: He goes out Left .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Girls , everybody in town was there ! I 'm sure even your father himself could n't have complained .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Well , you know he always found fault with my parties being too mixed . He would n't realize I could n't throw over all my old set when I married into his ,— not that I ever acknowledged I was your father 's inferior . I consider my family was just as good as his , only we were Presbyterians !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Mother , dear , take off your gloves .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I thought I had .Crying .I 'm so heartbroken I do n't know what I 'm doing .

div.stage: Taking off her gloves .
BLANCHE and CLARA comfort their mother .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Here 's the tea —

div.stage: JORDAN and LEONARD enter with large , silver tray , with tea , cups , and thin bread-and-butter sandwiches . They place them on small tea-table which JESSICA arranges for them .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I 'm afraid I can n't touch it .

div.stage: Taking her place behind tea-table and biting eagerly into a sandwich .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Dryly .Try .

div.stage: BLANCHE pours tea for them all , which they take in turn .

lg.l: One thing I was furious about ,— did you see the
Witherspoons here at the house ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I did .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: The idea ! When I 've never called on them . They are the worst social pushers I 've ever known .

div.stage: She takes another sandwich .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Trying to make people think they are on our visiting list ! Using even a funeral to get in !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: But I was glad the Worthings were here , and I thought it sweet of old Mr. Dormer to go even to the cemetery .Voice breaks a little .He never goes to balls any more , and , they say , catches cold at the slightest change of temperature .

div.stage: She takes a third sandwich .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: A great many people loved father .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Irritably .Spoken very plaintively .They ought to 've . It was really foolish the way he was always doing something for somebody ! How good these sandwiches are !

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Shall we have to economize now , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Of course not ; how dare you suggest such an injustice to your father , and before the flowers are withered on his grave !Again becoming tearful .JORDAN enters Left with a small silver tray , heaping full of letters .Has the new writing paper come ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Who takes the letters and looks through them , giving some to her mother .Yes .

div.stage: BLANCHE reads a letter , and passes it to JESSICA .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Is the black border broad enough ? They said it was the thing .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: If you had it any broader , you 'd have to get white ink to write with !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Sweetly .Do n't be impertinent , darling !

div.stage: Reading another letter .

Enter MISS RUTH HUNTER . She is an unmarried woman between thirty and forty years of age , handsome , distinguished ; an aristocrat , without any pretensions ; simple , unaffected , and direct in her effort to do kindnesses where they are not absolutely undeserved . She enters the room as if she carried with her an atmosphere of pure ozone . This affects all those in it . She is dressed in deep mourning and wears a thick chiffon veil , which she removes as she enters .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Oh ! you 're having tea !

div.stage: Glad that they are .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Taking a second cup .I thought the children ought to .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Of course they ought and so ought you , if you have n't .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Oh , I 've trifled with something .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Sit here , Aunt Ruth .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Will you have a cup , Aunt Ruth ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes , dear , I 'm feeling very hungry .

div.stage: Sitting on the sofa beside JESSICA and pressing her hand as she does so .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Hungry ! How can you !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Because I 'm not a hypocrite !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Whimpering .I suppose that 's a slur at me !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: If the slipper fits ! But I confess I have n't eaten much for several days ; I could n't touch anything this morning , and I begin to feel exhausted ; I must have food and , thank Heaven , I want it . Thank you .

div.stage: To BLANCHE , taking the cup from her .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I think it 's awful , Ruth , and I feel I have a right to say it — I think you owed it to my feelings to have worn a long veil ; people will think you did n't love your brother .

lg.l: Will they ? Let them ! You know as well as I do that
George loathed the very idea of crêpe and all display of mourning .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Feeling out of her element , changes the subject .You stayed behind ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes . I wanted to be the last there .Her voice chokes ; she tries to control herself .Ah ! you see my nerves are all gone to pieces . I wo n't cry any more !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I do n't see how you could bear it — staying ; but you never had any heart , Ruth .

lg.stage: Mechanically , biting her lips hard to keep the tears back .
lg.l: Have n't I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: My darling husband always felt that defect in you .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: George ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: He resented your treatment of me , and often said so .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Very quietly , but with determination .Please be careful . Do n't talk to me like this about my brother , Florence — or you 'll make me say something I shall be sorry for .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I do n't care ! It wore on him , the way you treated me . I put up with it for his sake , but it helped undermine his health .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Florence , stop !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: In foolish anger , the resentment of years bursting out .I wo n't stop ! I 'm alone now , and the least you can do is to see that people who 've fought shy of me take me up and give me my due . You 've been a cruel , selfish sister-in-law , and your own brother saw and hated you for it !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Mother !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Outraged .Send your daughters out of the room ; I wish to answer you alone .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Frightened .No ! what you have to say to me I prefer my children to hear !

div.stage: CLARA comes over to her mother and puts her arm about her .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I can n't remain quiet any longer . George —She almost breaks down , but she controls herself .This funeral is enough , with its show and worldliness ! I do n't believe there was a soul in the church you did n't see ! Look at your handkerchief ! Real grief is n't measured by the width of a black border . I 'm ashamed of you , Florence ! I never liked you very much , although I tried to for your husband 's sake , but now I 'm even more ashamed of you . My dear brother is gone , and there need be no further bond between us , but I want you to understand the true reason why , from to-day , I keep away from you . This funeral was revolting to me !— a show spectacle , a social function , and for him who you know hated the very thing .She stops a moment to control her tears and her anger .I saw the reporters there , and I heard your message to them , and I contradicted it . I begged them not to use your information , and they were gentlemen and promised me not to . You are , and always have been , a silly , frivolous woman . I do n't doubt you loved your husband as much as you could any man , but it was n't enough for me ; he was worth being adored by the best and noblest woman in the world . I 've stood by all these years , trying with my love and silent sympathy to be some comfort to him — but I saw the disappointment and disillusionment eat away the very hope of happiness out of his heart . I tried to help him by helping you in your foolish ambitions , doing what I could to give my brother 's wife the social position his name entitled her to !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: That 's not true ; I 've had to fight it out all alone !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: It was not my fault if my best friends found you intolerable ; I could n't blame them . Well , now it 's over ! George is at rest , please God . You are a rich woman to do what you please . Go , and do it ! and Heaven forgive you for ruining my brother 's life ! I 'm sorry to have said all this before your children . Blanche , you know how dearly I love you , and I hope you have forgiven me by now for my opposition to your marriage .

lg.l: Of course I 've forgiven you , but you were always unjust to
Dick .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes ; I did n't like your husband then , and I did n't believe in him , but I like him better now . And I am going to put all my affairs in his hands . I could n't show — surely — a better proof of confidence and liking than that : to trust him as I did — your father . I hope I shall see much of you and Jessica . As for you , Clara , I must be honest —

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Interrupting her .Oh , I know you 've always hated me ! The presents you gave the other girls were always twice as nice as I got !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Sympathetically .Come here , darling .

div.stage: CLARA goes and puts her arms about her mother 's neck .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: You are your mother 's own child , Clara , and I never could pretend anything I did n't feel .She turns to BLANCHE and JESSICA , who stand side by side .You two are all I have left in the world of my brother .She kisses them , and lets the tears come , this time without struggling .Take pity on your old-maid aunt and come and see me , wo n't you , often —Trying to smile away her tears .And now good-by !

sp.speaker: JESSICA AND RUTH
sp.p: Taking her hands .Good-by .

div.stage: RUTH looks about the room to say good-by to it ; she cries and hurriedly begins pulling down her veil , and starts to go out as JORDAN enters Left and announces “ Mr. Mason ! ”
MRS. HUNTER fluffs her hair a little and hopes she looks becoming .
MASON is a typical New Yorker , well built , well preserved , dignified , and good-looking ,— a solid man in every sense of the word .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Meeting RUTH , shakes hands with her .Miss Hunter .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I am just going , Mr. Mason .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: You must stay . I sent word to your house this morning to meet me here .

div.stage: Shakes hands with the others .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I was here all night .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Will you have some tea ? The children were hungry .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: No , thank you .To BLANCHE .Is n't your husband here ?

div.stage: JORDAN , at a signal from MRS. HUNTER , removes the tea things .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No , he left us at the door when we came back .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Did n't he get a letter from me this morning asking him to meet me here ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Oh , yes , he did mention a letter at breakfast , but my thoughts were away . He has been very much worried lately over his affairs ; he does n't confide in me , but I see it . I wish you could advise him , Mr. Mason .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: I cannot advise your husband if he wo n't ask my advice . I do n't think we 'll wait for Mr. Sterling .

div.stage: Gives chair to MRS. HUNTER .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I suppose you 've come about all the horrid business . Why not just tell us how much our income is , and let all the details go . I really think the details are more than I can bear to-day .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: That can be certainly as you wish ; but I felt — as your business adviser — and besides I promised my old friend , your husband — it was my duty to let you know how matters stand with the least possible delay .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Beginning to break down .George ! George !

div.stage: RUTH looks at her , furious , and bites her lips hard . JESSICA is standing with her back toward them .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Well , then —

div.stage: He is interrupted by MRS. HUNTER , who sees JESSICA .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Jess ! How rude you are ! Turn around this minute !JESSICA does not move .What do you mean ! Excuse me , Mr. Mason ! Jess ! Such disrespect to your father 's will ! Turn around !Angry .Do you hear me ?

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: With her back still turned , her shoulders shaking , speaks in a voice broken with sobs .Leave me alone ! Leave me alone —

div.stage: She sits in a chair beside her and leans her arms upon its back and buries her face in her arms .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: With her hand on her mother 's arm .Mother ! Do n't worry her !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Go on , please , Mr. Mason , and remember , spare us the details . What is our income ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Mrs. Hunter , there is no income .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Quietly , not at all grasping what he means .No income ! How is our money —

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: I am sorry to say there is no money .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Echoes weakly .No money ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Not a penny !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Realizing now what he means , cries out in a loud , hard , amazed voice .What !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: With her hand on her shoulder .Mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I do n't believe it !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: To MASON .My good friend , do you mean that literally — that my brother died without leaving any money behind him ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: For his wife and family ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: I mean just that .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: But how ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Yes , tell us the details — every one of them ! You can n't imagine the shock this is to me !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Hunter sent for me two days before he died , and told me things had gone badly with him last year , but it seemed impossible to retrench his expenses .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Are you listening , Florence ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Yes , of course I am ; your brother was a very extravagant man !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: This year , with his third daughter coming out , there was need of more money than ever . He was harassed nearly to death with financial worries .RUTH begins to cry softly . MRS. HUNTER gets angrier and angrier .And finally , in sheer desperation , and trusting to the advice of the Storrings , he risked everything he had with them in the Consolidated Copper . The day after , he was taken ill. You know what happened . The Storrings , Hunter , and others were ruined absolutely ; the next day Hunter died .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Poor George ! Why did n't he come to me ; he must have known that everything I had was his !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: He was too ill when the final blow came to realize it .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Angry .But his life insurance ,— there was a big policy in my name .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: He had been obliged to let that lapse .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: You mean I have n't even my life insurance ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: As I said , there is nothing , except this house , and that is —

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Rises indignantly and almost screams in angry hysterics .Mortgaged , I presume ! Oh , it 's insulting ! It 's an indignity . It 's — it 's — Oh , well , it 's just like my husband , there !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Mother !

div.stage: RUTH rises , and , taking MASON 'S arm , leads him aside .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: To BLANCHE .Oh , do n't talk to me now ! You always preferred your father , and now you 're punished for it ! He has wilfully left your mother and sisters paupers !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: How can you speak like that ! Surely you know father must have suffered more than we could when he realized he was leaving nothing for you .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Yes , and it was for us too that he lost all . It was our extravagance .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Hush ! How dare you side against me , too ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Florence —

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Well , Ruth , what do you think of your brother now ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: To her mother .Do n't !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: By whom were the arrangements for to-day made ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: My son-in-law had most pressing business , and his friend —

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: The friend of all of us —

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Yes , of course , Mr . Warden saw to everything .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: He will be here any moment !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: When he comes , will you send him on to me , please ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Very well . Good-by .Shakes hands with BLANCHE .I am very sorry to have been the bearer of such bad news .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Shaking hands with him .Please overlook anything I may have said ; at such a moment , with the loss of all my money — and my dear husband — I do n't know what to say !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Naturally .To the others .Good-by .To RUTH , who follows him .I 'll come to see you in the morning .

div.stage: As they shake hands .

lg.l: And I can then tell you what I settle here now .
Florence , I 'm very sorry —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Oh ! You ! Sorry !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes , very , very sorry ,— first , that I spoke as I did just now .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: It 's too late to be sorry for that now .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: No , it is n't , and I 'll prove to you I mean it . Come , we 'll talk things over .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Go away ! I do n't want you to prove anything to me !MRS. HUNTER and CLARA sit side by side on the sofa . BLANCHE and JESSICA are in chairs near the table . RUTH sits beside BLANCHE . MRS. HUNTER has something the manner of porcupines and shows a set determination to accept nothing by way of comfort or expedient . BLANCHE looks hopeful and ready to take the helm for the family . JESSICA will back up BLANCHE .My happiness in this world is over . What have I to live for ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Your children !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Beggars like myself !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: But your children will work for you .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Work ! I see myself .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: So do I .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: My children work ! Do n't be absurd !

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: It is not absurd ! I can certainly earn my own living somehow and so can Clara .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Doing what , I should like to know ! I see myself !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Jess is right . I 'll take care of this family — father always said I was “ his own child . ” I 'll do my best to take his place .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I will gladly give Jessica a home .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Whimpers .You 'd rob me of my children , too !

lg.l: Thank you , Aunt Ruth , but I must stay with mother and be
Blanche 's right-hand man !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I might go on the stage .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: My dear , smart people do n't any more .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I 'd like to be a sort of Anna Held .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: I do n't see why I could n't learn typewriting , Blanche ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Huh ! Why , you could never even learn to play the piano ; I do n't think you 'd be much good at typewriting .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: You want to be a typewriter , because in the papers they always have an old gentleman taking them to theatres and supper ! No , sir , if there is to be any “ old man 's darling ” in this family , I 'll be it !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Dryly .You 'll have to learn to spell correctly first !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Superciliously .Humph !

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: There are lots of ways nowadays for women to earn their living .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes , typewriting we will consider .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Never !

div.stage: No one pays any attention to her except CLARA , who agrees with her .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Jess , you learned enough to teach , did n't you ?— even at that fashionable school your mother sent you to ?

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Oh , yes , I think I could teach .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Never !

div.stage: Still no one pays any attention except CLARA who again agrees with her .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: No , indeed ! I would n't teach !

lg.l: If we only knew some nice elderly woman who wanted a companion ,
Jess would be a godsend .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: If she was a nice old lady with lots of money and delicate health , I would n't mind that position myself .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Clara , you seem to take this matter as a supreme joke !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: With mock humility .May I speak ?She waits . All turn to her . A moment 's , silence .MAY I speak ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes , yes . Go on , Florence ; do n't you see we 're listening ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I did n't know ! I 've been so completely ignored in this entire conversation . But there is one thing for the girls — the easiest possible way for them to earn their living — which you do n't seem for a moment to have thought of !

div.stage: She waits with a smile of coming triumph on her face .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Nursing !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Disgusted .No !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Manicuring ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Darling !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Designing dresses and hats ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Book-keeping ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Then what in the world is it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Marriage !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Oh , of course !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Humph !

div.stage: JESSICA and BLANCHE exchange glances .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: That young Mr. Trotter would be a fine catch for Jess .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Who loathes him !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Do n't be old-fashioned ! He 's very nice .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: A little cad , trying to get into society — nice occupation for a man !

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Mother , you can n't be serious .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Why would n't he do for me ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: He would ! The very thing !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: We 'll see , darling ; I think Europe is the place for you . I do n't believe all the titles are gobbled up yet .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Jess , I might get you some women friends of mine , to whom you could go mornings and answer their letters .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I should not allow my daughter to go in that capacity to the house of any woman who had refused to call on her mother , which is the way most of your friends have treated me .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Do you realize , Florence , this is a question of bread and butter , a practical suggestion of life , which has nothing whatever to do with the society columns of the daily papers ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I do not intend that my daughters shall lose their positions because their father has been — what shall we call it — criminally negligent of them .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Rising .How dare you ! You are to blame for it all . If you say another word injurious to my brother 's memory , I 'll leave this house and let you starve for all I 'll do for you .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Aunt Ruth , please , for father 's sake —

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Well , this house is ours , anyway !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: That is what I 've been thinking of . The house is yours . It 's huge . You do n't need it . You must either give it up altogether —

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Interrupts .What ! Leave it ? My house ! Never !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Or — let out floors to one or two friends ,— bachelor friends . Mr. Mason , perhaps —

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Interrupts , rising , furious .Take in boarders !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Who has listened aghast , now rises in outraged dignity ; she stands a moment glaring at BLANCHE , then speaks .Take —She chokes .That is the last straw !

div.stage: And she sweeps from the room Right .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Mama ! Mama !

div.stage: She goes out after her mother .
The other three women watch the two leave the room , then turn and look at each other .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: We 'll manage somehow , only I think it would be easier for us to discuss all practical matters by ourselves .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: And I want you to understand this , girls ,— I represent your dear father ; half of everything I have is yours , and you must promise me always to come to me for everything .

div.stage: STERLING enters suddenly Left .

He is a man of thirty-eight or forty , a singularly attractive personality ; he is handsome and distinguished . His hair is grayer than his years may account for and his manner betrays a nervous system overtaxed and barely under control . At the moment that he enters he is evidently laboring under some especial , and only half-concealed , nervous strain . In spite of his irritability at times with his wife , there is an undercurrent of tenderness which reveals his real love for BLANCHE .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Oh , you 're all here ! Have I missed old Mason ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes , but Blanche will tell you what he had to say . I 'm going upstairs to try and pacify your mother . We must n't forget she has a hard time ahead of her .

div.stage: She goes out Right with JESSICA .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I suppose Mason came about the will and your father 's affairs ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Yes , you ought to have been here .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Irritably .But I could n't — I told you I could n't !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Do you realize , dear , that you have n't been able to do anything for me for a long time ? Lately , even I hardly ever see you — I stay home night after night alone .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: That 's your own fault , dear ; Ned Warden 's always ready to take you anywhere you like .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: With the ghost of a jest .But do you think it 's quite right for me to take up all Mr . Warden 's time ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Why not , if he likes it ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: And do n't you think people will soon talk ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Darling ! People always talk , and who cares !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: It 's months since you showed me any sign of affection , and now when my heart is hungrier than ever for it ,— you know how I loved my father ,— I long for sympathy from you , and you have n't once thought to take me , your wife , in your arms and hold me close and comfort me .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I 'm sorry , old girl , I 'm really sorry .Embracing her affectionately .And surely you know I do n't love any other woman in the world but you .He kisses her .It 's only because I 've been terribly worried . I do n't want to bother you with business , but I 've been in an awful hole for money . I tried to make a big coup in Wall Street the other day and only succeeded getting in deeper , and for the last few days I 've been nearly distracted .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Why did n't you tell me ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I thought I 'd get out of it with this Consolidated Copper without worrying you .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: You were in that , too ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: How do you mean I , “ too ” ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Mr. Mason has just told us father lost everything in it .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Aghast .You do n't mean your father has n't left any money ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Forgetting everything but what this means to him .Nothing ! But I was counting on your share to save me ! What did the damned old fool mean ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Dick !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Forgive me , I did n't mean to say that .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Oh , who are you ! What are you ! You are not the man I thought when I married you ! Every day something new happens to frighten me , to threaten my love for you !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No , no , do n't say that , old girl .

div.stage: He tries to take her hand .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: What right have you to criticise my father , to curse him — and to-day !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I do n't know what I 'm saying , Blanche . Try to forgive me . I would n't have thought of such a thing as his money to-day if it was n't the only thing that can save me from — disgrace .

div.stage: His voice sinking almost to a whisper and the man himself sinking into a chair .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Disgrace ! How ? What disgrace ?

div.stage: Going to him .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I can n't explain it ; you would n't understand .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: You must explain it ! Your disgrace is mine .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Alarmed at having said so much , tries to retract a little .Disgrace was too strong a word — I did n't mean that . I 'm in trouble . I 'm in trouble . Good God , can n't you see it ? And if you love me , why do n't you leave me alone ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: How can I go on loving you without your confidence ?— without ever being suffered to give you any sympathy ? Doll wives are out of fashion , and even if they were n't , I could never be one .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Laughing .My dear , I 'd never accuse you of being stuffed with sawdust .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Oh , and now you joke about it . Take care , Dick .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: What 's this , a threat ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Yes , if you like to call it that . You 've been putting me more and more completely out of your life ; take care that I do n't finish your work and go the last step .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Seizing her roughly by the wrist .The last step ! What do you mean by that ?Holding her hand more roughly .You dare to be unfaithful to me !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: What ! You could think I meant that ! Ugh ! How could you ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Well , what did you mean then ? Eh ?

div.stage: Pulling her up close to him , her face close to his . She realizes first by the odor , then by a searching look at his face , that he is partly under the influence of liquor .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: With pathetic shame .Let me go ! I see what 's the matter with you , but the reason is no excuse ; you 've been drinking .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Dropping her hand .Ugh ! The usual whimper of a woman !

div.stage: RUTH reënters Right .

lg.l: Well , Blanche , dear , your mother 's in a calmer frame of mind , and
I must go . Dick , can you lunch with me to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Hesitating , not caring about it .Er — to-morrow ?— er —

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Oh , only for business . I must have a new business man now to do all that he did for me , and I 'm going to try to make up to you for not having been always your — best friend , by putting my affairs in your hands .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Serious , uneasy , almost frightened .Aunt Ruth —

div.stage: She stops .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: What , dear ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Nothing .

div.stage: She gives STERLING a searching , steady look and keeps her eyes upon him , trying to read his real self .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Continues to STERLING .Mr. Mason is coming to me in the morning , and if you will lunch with me at one , I will then be able to give all the papers over to you .

div.stage: STERLING , who up to this time has been almost dumbfounded by this sudden good fortune , now collects himself , and speaks delightedly but with sufficient reserve of his feelings . BLANCHE does not take her eyes from STERLING 'S face .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Aunt Ruth , I thank you from the bottom of my heart , and I will do my best .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Quickly .Promise her , Dick , before me — give her your word of honor — you will be faithful to Aunt Ruth 's trust .

div.stage: He answers BLANCHE 'S look steadily with a hard gaze of his own .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: His acceptance of my trust is equal to that , Blanche .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: It is of course , is n't it , Dick ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Of course .

div.stage: BLANCHE is not content , but has to satisfy herself with this .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: To-morrow at one , then .

div.stage: She starts to go .
JORDAN enters Left .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Mr . Warden .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I can n't wait . Good-by .

div.stage: She goes out Left .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: We will see Mr . Warden .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Yes , madam .

div.stage: He goes out Left .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Blanche , go to your mother and ask her to see Ned to thank him . I want a minute 's talk with him if you do n't mind .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Pathetically .What difference does it make , Dick , if I do mind ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Do n't say that , old girl , and do n't think it .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Dick , you are honest , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Without flinching .What a question , Blanche !

div.stage: JORDAN enters Left announcing “ Mr . Warden . ” WARDEN enters , and JORDAN goes out .

EDWARD WARDEN , though in reality scarcely younger than STERLING , looks at least ten years his junior . He is good-looking , practical , a reasoning being , and self-controlled . He is a thorough American , with the fresh and strong ideals of his race , and with the feeling of romance alive in the bottom of his heart .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: In enormous relief , greets him joyfully .Ned , what do you think ! The greatest news going !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Dick !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Excuse me , Blanche , I forgot ; but Ned will know how I can n't help being glad .

div.stage: WARDEN goes to MRS. STERLING .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Shaking NED 'S hand .And Mr . Warden knows nothing could make me “ glad ” to-day . Thank you for all your kindness —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Do n't thank me ; it was nothing .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Yes , please let me thank you all I can ; it wo n't be half what I feel , but I want to know that you know even my silence is full of gratitude for all you 've done for my mother , sisters , and me .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Yes , we 're all immensely indebted to you , Ned , old man .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I will tell mother . I know she wants to see you .

div.stage: She goes out Right .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Speaking with suppressed excitement and uncontrollable gladness , unable to keep it back any longer .Ned , my wife 's aunt , Miss Hunter , has put all her business in my hands .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Made you her agent ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Yes ! What a godsend ! Hunter did n't leave a cent .

div.stage: A moment 's pause of astonishment .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: It seems he 's been losing for a long time . Everything he had he lost in the copper crash .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: But this is awful ! What will Mrs. Hunter and her two young daughters do ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I do n't know . I had n't thought of that .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You 'll have to think of it . STERLING . I ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Of course you 'll have to help them .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I can n't ! Look here , I did n't tell you the truth about my affairs last week , when I struck you for that loan .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You do n't mean to say you were n't straight with me ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Oh , I only did n't want to frighten you till I 'd got the money ; if you had made me the loan , I 'd have owned up afterwards all right enough .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Owned up what ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: That I told you a pack of lies — that I have n't any security !— that I have n't anything but debts .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Strongly .Good things to borrow on ! Look here , Dick , how long have we been friends ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Since that day at boarding school when you took a licking for something I did .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: What I mean is we were pals at school , chums at college , stanch friends for twenty years .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Hell ! Are we as old as all that ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Inseparable friends till the last two years .

div.stage: STERLING 'S eyes shift .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I 've been overworked lately , and everything has gone wrong !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Comes up to him , and speaks firmly but still friendly .You yourself have gone wrong !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: On the defensive .What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Why did you take your business out of my hands ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: The law did n't pay me enough . I thought I 'd try a little amateur stockbroking .

div.stage: Smiling insincerely .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You did n't want me to know what you were doing !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Rats !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You did n't want me to know what funds — whose funds — you were using — misusing .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Ugly .What !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Whose money you were gambling with !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Have you been spying on me ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Your wife 's money !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Well , she 's my wife , and you do n't know what you 're talking about !

div.stage: He turns from him and picks up a book from the table upside down and pretends to read it .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You stole from me once when you were a boy !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No ! I did n't !

div.stage: Throwing the book down .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You lie ! Do you hear me ? You lie !He waits a second . STERLING does nothing .I was never sure till to-day ! I fought against ever thinking it , believing my suspicions were an injustice to you , but little things were always disappearing out of my rooms — finally , even money . Lately , that old suspicion has come back with a fuller force , and to-day it became a certainty .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: How to-day ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Because if it were n't true , you 'd have knocked me down just now when I called you first a thief and twice a liar !

div.stage: He stands squarely facing him . STERLING stands facing him also , surprised , taken off his guard .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Oh , come , you 're joking !WARDEN makes an angry exclamation .Why 're you telling me all this now ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Because I want you to be careful . I want you to know some one is watching you ! Some one who knows what you 've come to ! Some one who knows you can n't resist temptation ! Some one who knows money not yours has stuck to your fingers !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: You mind your own business .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I 'll mind yours if it 's necessary to protect people who are dear to me !

div.stage: STERLING looks at him with a sudden suspicion .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Insinuatingly .I did n't know you were particularly attached to Mrs. Hunter .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I 'm not .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Or to her two unmarried daughters !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Nor am I !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: With whispered intensity .By God , if you are in love with my wife !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: If you thought that out loud , I 'd knock you down !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Huh ! you talk as if you thought I were a coward !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No , not a physical coward — I 've seen you do too many plucky things — but a moral coward — yes , you are one !

div.stage: Straight to him , standing close and looking him squarely in the eyes .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Wavering .Oh , you 're too damned preachy !

div.stage: MRS. HUNTER enters Right with CLARA . MRS. HUNTER shakes hands with WARDEN silently , happy in the feeling that she is in great affliction , and satisfied with the appearance and impression she is making . She carries her handkerchief , with its black border , ready in her hand . CLARA has silently shaken hands with WARDEN , after her mother . She afterwards goes to STERLING and hands him several of the letters of condolence . She then goes to the window at Left , pulling aside the curtain , and stands looking out , rather bored , wishing she could go out and take a walk .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: We will never forget your kindness . Will the evening papers have anything in , do you think ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No , not before morning .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Sighs .Every one was there .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Where 's Blanche ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Upstairs . She said she was going after Aunt Ruth .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Frightened .After Aunt Ruth ?Strongly .What for ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I do n't know .Whimpering .I 'm not considered in the family any longer !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I shall stop and take her home .

div.stage: JORDAN enters .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Will you see visitors , madam ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No .

div.stage: He goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: “ No ” ? Yes , we will ! I need to see some one , or I shall break down . Go upstairs , Clara !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: No , why need I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: You 're not out yet .

lg.l: I do n't care ! At this rate I 'll never get “ out . ” Who are they ,
Jordan ?

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Miss Sillerton , Miss Godesby , and Mr. Trotter , miss .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I must go , Mrs. Hunter .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Relieved .So sorry . Could you go straight to Mr. Mason ? He wishes to see you ?

div.stage: Shaking hands .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: WARDEN inclines his head to CLARA .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Lightly .Good-by !

div.stage: WARDEN goes out Left .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I do n't think we ought to receive Mr. Trotter .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Pshaw ! why not ? If there 's really any idea of my mar —

div.stage: She stops short , silenced by a look from her mother and an indication toward JORDAN .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Show them up , Jordan .JORDAN bows and goes out .How do I look , dear ?

div.stage: Arranges her handkerchief .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Looking in the mirror .How do I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: With her back to CLARA .I asked you first how I looked !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Not observing .Oh , you 're all right , how am I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Not looking at CLARA .Charming ! We 'll go upstairs and come down again ; I do n't think it nice to be found here as if we were expecting visitors .

div.stage: They go out Right .
JORDAN steps into the room to announce the visitors , and seeing no one there , bows as the three pass him .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: The ladies will be down at once .

div.stage: He goes out Right .
The three turn , looking about the room with curiosity , as if the funeral might have made some difference in the house .

MISS SILLERTON is a handsome , attractive woman , most fashionably dressed and perfectly conventional in character and intelligence . MISS GODESBY is a little slow , more assertive , sharper of tongue , more acutely intelligent , and equally smartly dressed . She has still a remnant of real , sincere feeling buried under a cynical mask which her life in a fast set has developed for her self-preservation . TROTTER is a foolish young person , meaning well enough according to his lights , which are not of the biggest and brightest .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Classy house altogether !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Mrs. Hunter went to the most expensive decorator in town , and told him , no matter what it cost , to go ahead and do his worst !

div.stage: They all laugh and seat themselves comfortably .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Say ! The youngest daughter is a good looker — very classy .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: That 's the one we told you about , the one we want you to marry .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Yes , with your money and her cleverness , she 'll rubber neck you into the smartest push in town !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: You 've promised I shall know the whole classy lot before spring .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: So you will if you do as we tell you . But you must n't let society see that you know you 're getting in ; nothing pleases society so much as to think you 're a blatant idiot . It makes everybody feel you 're their equal — that 's why you get in .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I 've got a coach and can drive four-in-hand . I 've an automobile drag , and the biggest private yacht in the world building . I 'm going to have the most expensive house in Long Island , where the oysters come from , and I 've bought a lot in Newport twice as big as the swellest fellow 's there . I 've got a house in London and a flat in Paris , and I make money fly . I think I ought to be a cinch as a classy success .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Do n't be a yap ; flag Clara Hunter and you 're all right !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Her father 's position was the best in this country !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: But he 's dead .

div.stage: Sitting .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: A good thing for you , for he would never have stood for you !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: He 'd have had to — or do without me as a son-in-law — I would n't marry the Venus of Milo if her father did n't think I was good enough . I 'm no Dodo bird !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: It 's up to you now , Trotter ! Go in and win .

div.stage: Enter TOMPSON Right ; a decided change takes place in all their manners .

sp.speaker: TOMPSON
sp.p: Madam will be down at once , miss .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: TOMPSON goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Only stay a minute or two , Trotty — we 're doing our best for you , but we must look out for ourselves , too , and we 've come here to-day on business .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: How 'll we ever get the subject on to clothes ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Humph ! Do you think you can talk five minutes with Mrs. Hunter and not hit that topic ? It 's a bull 's eye !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I do n't see where I 'm going to come into this classy conversation .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: You see , Trotty , they brought over piles of clothes from Europe this year , and we want to get hold of them before any one else has a chance — get ‘ em cheap before they have an idea anybody else 'll buy them .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Who buy what ?

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: We — buy their winter clothes .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: For Heaven 's sake !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Laugh , you silly ! I heard the Reed girls planning to come to-morrow . They did n't dare come to-day . Those girls have n't any sand ! They 're always getting left .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: You two are Dodo birds !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I say , Eleanor , you 're such a lobster about prices and Mrs. Hunter 's no idiot , we 'd better agree on some sort of a signal ! Listen ! if you like a gown very much , ask the price , then say to me , “ My dear , your hat pin is coming out . ” And if I think it 's a bargain , I 'll say , “ So it is , thank you ; wo n't you put it in for me ? ” And if I think Mrs. Hunter 's trying to stick you , I 'll say “ No , it is n't ; it 's always like that . ”

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: All right .

div.stage: MRS. HUNTER and CLARA enter Right . The manner of MISS SILLERTON and MISS GODESBY changes immediately . They speak with rather subdued voices , in the tone of conventional sympathy which is usually adopted on such occasions . MRS. HUNTER also assumes the manner of a martyr to grief . CLARA is casual and hard .

lg.l: Dear Mrs. Hunter .
Clara , dear .

div.stage: She kisses her .
MISS GODESBY goes to MRS. HUNTER and shakes hands while MISS SILLERTON crosses to CLARA ; Trotter shakes hands with MRS. HUNTER as MISS GODESBY goes to CLARA .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I hope you do n't think my coming an intrusion .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Not at all .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I felt we must stop in for a few minutes to give you our love and sympathy and find out how you are .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I 've been through a terrible strain . My loss is even greater than I could ever possibly imagine .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Who misinterprets her mother 's remark .Yes , indeed , I should say it was !

div.stage: MRS. HUNTER stops her with a warning look .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: But every one has been most kind . Lady Hopeton sent me a beautiful long letter to-day .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: And I 'm glad to find you looking so well . Black suits you !

div.stage: She exchanges a knowing glance with MISS SILLERTON .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know , Julia ; I 've always thought black very trying for me .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh , no ! every one 's saying just the reverse !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: But — I suppose clothes do n't interest you , Mr. Trotter ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Oh , yes , they do , out of sight !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Well , I wish you could have seen the beautiful things we brought over with us !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Julia and I were just speaking about it , and pitying you from the bottom of our hearts .

div.stage: MISS SILLERTON and MISS GODESBY again exchange surreptitious glances .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Every one 's been most kind .

div.stage: There is an awkward pause for a moment , no one knowing quite what to say . Both MISS GODESBY and MISS SILLERTON have started the conversation in the direction of clothing and are fearful of the topic being changed . As the pause becomes embarrassing , they look helplessly from one to the other , and all five , suddenly and at once , make an ineffectual effort to say something — or nothing . Out of the general confusion MRS. HUNTER comes to the front , mistress of the situation . ] Are you going to stay in New York this winter , Mr. Trotter ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Yes , I 'm negotiating for one of the biggest classy building plots on upper Fifth Avenue .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: To MISS GODESBY .I saw in the papers you were at the dance last night .

div.stage: MISS GODESBY nods and motions surreptitiously to TROTTER to go . He , however , does n't understand .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: With interest again in life .Oh , were you ? What did you wear ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh , dowdy old things . I have n't bought my winter frocks yet .

div.stage: She repeats this casually as if to herself .
MISS SILLERTON motions to TROTTER to go , but he has forgotten and still does n't understand .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: You warned us not to let you forget your engagement !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: What engagement ?

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: How do we know ! we only know you said you had to go !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Never said so ! Oh !As it dawns upon him .Oh , yes ! of course .He rises .Very sorry — must be off . Only dropped in — er — that is , came in to express my respectful sympathy .

div.stage: Shaking hands with MRS. HUNTER .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Who rises .I hope you will come and see us again .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Do ! It 'll be a godsend ! We 'll be dull as ditchwater here this winter !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I shall be delighted to call again . Good-by .He bows to Clara . In his embarrassment he starts to shake hands all over again , but , realizing his mistake , laughs nervously .Oh , I have already .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Good-by , Trotter .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Do n't forget we 're booked with you at Sherry 's .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Whose treat ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh ! Yours , of course —

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I say , why can n't I stay ? I wo n't interfere .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Oh , do stay , Mr. Trotter !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh , do stay !

div.stage: Suggesting by her tone that he must n't dare to remain .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Good !

div.stage: TROTTER remains , and they all settle themselves again for a long stay .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: By the way , you were speaking just now of your winter frocks . It occurs to me — of course I do n't know as I really want to dispose of them , but — er —

div.stage: She hesitates purposely .

lg.l: Oh , would you ?
lg.stage: Rising , she takes a chair nearer to MRS. HUNTER .
lg.l: You dear thing !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: The dresses are no use to us now , and when we 're out of mourning — they 'll be out of style . You could wear Jess ’ things perfectly , Julia .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: And even something of yours could be made over for us .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: But I 'm so much older than you !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Thoughtlessly .Yes , but you never dress appropriately to your age .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Laughing delightedly .That 's pretty good !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Saves herself .You know what I mean , you always look so youthful , you can n't dress any older .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Rising .Clara , dear , go upstairs and have Tompson bring down my Worth dress and Jess ’ Doucet and your Paquin .She goes with CLARA to the door , Right , and then whispers to her .If you remember , do n't tell what we paid — we ought to get nearly double out of these girls — and warn Tompson not to be surprised at anything she hears .

div.stage: MISS GODESBY and MISS SILLERTON exchange glances . CLARA goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: It seems as if I had no further interest in clothes , anyway .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Do n't say that . Every one I 've seen this afternoon is wildly enthusiastic over your mourning .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Well , I went straight to Madame O'Hoolihan and gave her carte blank !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I would n't like to be the ice man when your bill comes in !— and clothes abroad are so much cheaper .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Thoughtlessly .Oh , half !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Quickly .You see you 'll be doing us a really great favor letting us have some of your things !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Realizing her nearly fatal error .Oh ! Oh , yes — but — er — I must say that we found prices while in Paris this year rather atrocious !

div.stage: CLARA reënters Right .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Sighs .O dear ! It breaks my heart not to wear my ball dress , my dear Julia ; it was designed specially for me . I told Marie to put it on , mama ; my clothes fit her perfectly , and I thought it would show so much better what it is .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Here they are .

div.stage: Rises as TOMPSON enters Right .

sp.speaker: TOMPSON
sp.p: Mrs. Hunter 's reception gown .

div.stage: Displaying it .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Oh , this is a beauty !

div.stage: She takes the costume and drapes it over a chair . MISS GODESBY and MISS SILLERTON come closer to examine .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Tompson .—Taking her to one side , whispers .— I forget ; do you remember what I paid for this dress ?

sp.speaker: TOMPSON
sp.p: Whispers back .One hundred and sixty dollars , madam .

lg.l: Oh , yes . Do n't say anything .
Do you like it ?

lg.stage: At the same time . MISS GODESBY . Immensely . It 's great ! }
lg.l: Perfectly lovely ! }

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Hesitates .I forget just what I paid for it , but I believe it was two hundred dollars .

div.stage: CLARA half exclaims in astonishment , but on being pinched surreptitiously on the arm by MRS. HUNTER she grasps the situation and starts in to do her share .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Oh , no , mama ! I 'm sure it was more than that !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Well , perhaps it was two — twenty or two — twenty-five .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: That 's cheap , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Shut up .

div.stage: TOMPSON 'S face is always a perfect blank , showing no expression or surprise ; she has lived with MRS. HUNTER for many years and “ knows her business . ”

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: In a very different tone of voice , influenced by the big price .Of course , I see it 's made of the best material . But it is n't my color .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: It 's the very latest shade .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Yes , I know ; but I think as you said a little while ago , perhaps it is a trifle too old for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I might let you have it for a little less ; say one hundred and eighty .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Thank you very much . I 'll think it over .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: What 's the other ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: This is a dinner dress of Jess ’ .

div.stage: Holding it up to her own waist .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Carried away by the dress .Oh , lovely ,— perfectly charming ,— an adorable gown !

div.stage: MISS GODESBY pulls her arm and tries to make her less enthusiastic .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: To CLARA and MRS. HUNTER .Excuse me .

div.stage: She takes MISS SILLERTON to one side and whispers in her ear .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Aloud .I can n't help it . I 'm crazy about the dress !

div.stage: Meanwhile MRS. HUNTER and TOMPSON have whispered together .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: They said themselves this was the most successful frock they turned out this autumn .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: And how much is this one ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Very quickly , trying not to speak consciously .This was two hundred and seventy-five .

div.stage: CLARA bites her lips in surprise and winks visibly to TOMPSON , who gives no sign and is otherwise imperturbable .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: To MISS GODESBY , looking hard at her .My dear , your hat pin is coming out !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Looking hard at her .No , it is n't ; it 's always like that .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Going closer to her , whispers .Which does that mean ? I forget !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: It 's a gouge !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: I can n't help it ; I can n't resist .

sp.speaker: MISS HUNTER
sp.p: Whispers to CLARA .She 's going to take it ; I wish I 'd asked more .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Mrs. Hunter , I 'll take the dinner dress ! I 'm crazy about it !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I 'm glad to have you have it ; I 'm glad to be able to do you , in a way , a favor .

div.stage: MARIE at this moment enters dressed in the most exquisite ball dress of the very latest fashion and looks extremely lovely .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Here 's mine ! I could cry to think I 'll never wear it !

sp.speaker: MARIE
sp.p: Voila , madame !

div.stage: A short silence , while the women sit down and drink in the gown .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: In a subdued voice of awed admiration .Beautiful !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Great !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: To MISS GODESBY .I 'm stuck on the girl ; introduce me . She 's out of sight !

div.stage: MRS. HUNTER sighs long and loud ,— a sigh of appreciation and admiration . MARIE stands in the centre of the stage facing the audience .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: May we see her back ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Her entire back , if she turns around !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Turn around , Marie .

sp.speaker: MARIE
sp.p: Oui , madame .

div.stage: She turns her back — the dress is cut extremely in the back .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Rather !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: The way everything is made this year .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I 'm afraid my back is rather full of bones .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: They told us in Paris , bones were coming in !She takes a large American beauty rose from a vase on the piano and slips it down MARIE 'S back so that the dress seems much less décolleté .There , never too late to mend !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: How much is this one ?

div.stage: MISS GODESBY and MISS SILLERTON examine the dress .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Whispers to MRS. HUNTER .You paid two hundred for it !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Three hundred dollars . It is really superb .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Pulling MISS GODESBY around quickly .My dear , your hat pin is coming out !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Do n't be absurd !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: It 's my turn , sit down ; you got the last ! You wo n't mind my being frank , Mrs. Hunter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: On the defensive .Certainly not .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I think the price is too much .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Oh , go on , pay it !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Will you sign the check ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Excuse me !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I 'd give twice that if only I could wear it to one ball this winter !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I would n't part with it for a penny less . I could n't afford to .

div.stage: The manners and voices of all become a little strained .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: That is of course your affair .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Politely .We need n't keep Marie any longer , at any rate , need we ? You can go , Marie , and you too , Tompson .

div.stage: CLARA and MRS. HUNTER help place the other dresses on TOMPSON 'S arms .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: To MISS GODESBY , on the opposite side of the room , in a lowered voice .I 'll take it ; I 'm willing to pay that .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Do n't you dare interfere ! I want the gown , but I know she 'll come down ,— if she does n't , I 'll make a bluff at going . Then if she sticks to her price , I 'll come back and pay it .

div.stage: They turn to MRS. HUNTER .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Oh , Mrs. Hunter , may I see my dress just one more minute ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Certainly .

div.stage: She and CLARA come back with the dress .

lg.stage: To TOMPSON by the door at Right .
lg.l: Vite ! Come ! Come ! Jordan ‘ ave stole ze photograph machine of Mees
Clara , and he make now one pigsher of me in ze dress !

div.stage: Smiling mischievously , delighted , she goes out Right .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Thank you .

div.stage: She leaves her dress .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Take this too , Tompson .

sp.speaker: TOMPSON
sp.p: Yes , madam .

div.stage: MRS. HUNTER speaks to TOMPSON , aside , and CLARA , near them , watches the two visitors out of the corner of her eye .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Aside to MISS SILLERTON .I 'll leave my muff ; that 'll be a good excuse to come back .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Also in a lowered voice to MISS GODESBY .Dodo !

div.stage: TOMPSON goes out Right .
MRS. HUNTER and CLARA come back .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: You really could n't take less than three hundred ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I wish I could if only for your own sake ; but I really could n't in justice to myself .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I 'm very sorry — and I 'm afraid we must be going now .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Not believing they will go .Oh , must you ? Well , it was very kind of you to come .

div.stage: MISS GODESBY leaves her muff upon the table at the Left .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Shakes hands with MRS. HUNTER .Good-by .

div.stage: She goes on to CLARA .
MISS GODESBY comes to shake hands with MRS. HUNTER .

lg.l: I think you 're making a mistake not to take the dress ,
Julia dear .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Perhaps , but I really can n't go more than two hundred and fifty .

div.stage: MRS. HUNTER looks surreptitiously at CLARA , who slyly shakes her head to her mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Oh , quite impossible !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Good-by .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Good-by .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Good-by , Clara .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Frightened .Would you like to see the dress off ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh , my dear , it was as off as I would ever like to see it . Good-by .

lg.l: Good-by .
lg.stage: MISS SILLERTON and MISS GODESBY get to doorway Left .
lg.l: You wo n't take it ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Ca n't ! Good-by .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Dryly .You 're forgetting your muff !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Rubber !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Coming back for it .How stupid !

div.stage: She goes away to the door again in silence , which is full of suspense for all of them . As she reaches the door MRS. HUNTER speaks .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Look here , Julia , do n't say another word ; you shall have the dress for two hundred and fifty .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Rushing back , followed by all the others .You dear ! I 'm afraid you think I 've been rather nasty !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Oh , no , of course business is business , and I 'd rather you had it than see it wasted on some of our other friends who 'd be sights in it !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Good-by .Kisses her this time .I have n't said half I feel ; you 've been in my thoughts all these last few days .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Thank you , dear .

div.stage: Kisses her .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Shall we send around for the dresses in the morning ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Or I 'll send them .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: No , we wo n't trouble you .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Good-by !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER AND CLARA
sp.p: Good-by !

div.stage: MISS SILLERTON and MISS GODESBY go out Left , followed by TROTTER , who has joined in all the good-bys , and upon whom CLARA has more or less continuously kept her “ weather eye . ”

lg.l: I 'm perfectly sure if I 'd stuck to three hundred , Julia
Godesby would have sent around when she got home and paid it !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I 'm glad you did n't run the risk though , for we 'll need every cent we can get now .

div.stage: She runs her fingers rapidly over the piano keys .
BLANCHE reënters Right .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Why , I thought you 'd gone long ago .

lg.l: Jess begged me to stay with her . Try to understand her , mother ;
I think she will miss father more than any of us .

div.stage: JORDAN enters Left .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Mr . Warden has come back , madam .

div.stage: WARDEN enters Left .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Forgive my intruding so soon again , but did Mr. Mason leave a letter case of Mr. Hunter 's here ?

div.stage: BLANCHE begins looking for the case .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I have n't seen it ; I 'll ask the servants to look . Excuse me , I 'm quite tired out ; we 've been receiving a long visit of condolence .

div.stage: She goes out , Right , with CLARA , who links her arm in her mother 's .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Finding the case , which has fallen beneath the table .Here it is . Dear old pocket-book —

div.stage: Her voice breaks on the last word , and turning her face away to hide her tears , she hands him the well-worn letter case .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Mrs. Sterling , I 'm glad they left us alone , because Mr. Mason said he had n't been able to manage it — to see you alone — and yet he wanted you only to examine these . They are private papers of Mr. Hunter ; he thought they ought not to be destroyed without being read , and yet he hesitated to read them . We thought that duty devolved best upon you .He hands back the letter case .Shall I wait and take back the case to Mr. Mason with the papers you wish him to have ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Oh , no , I will send them ; I must n't keep you while I read them . I 'm always taking more of your time than I ought .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Speaks with sincerity , but without any suggestion of love-making .But never as much as I want to give you ! Do n't forget , Mrs. Sterling , what you promised me at your wedding ,— that your husband 's best man should be your best friend .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: And nobody knows what it means to a woman , even a happily married woman like me —This is spoken with a slight effort , as if she is persuading herself that she is a happily married woman .— to have an honest friend like you . It 's those people who have failed that say there is no such thing as a platonic friendship .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: We 'll prove them wrong .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: We will . Good-by , and thank you .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: And thank you !Starting to go , he turns .Shall I bring that Russian pianist around to play for you some day next week ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Do — I want some music .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Only let me know what day .He goes out Left . BLANCHE sits by the table and opens the case . She looks first at a memoranda and reads what is on the outside .A business memoranda . Lists of bonds .She opens and looks at the next paper only a second , and then closes it .This , Mr. Mason will understand better than I .She puts it back in the pocket case . She finds a photograph in the case .My picture !—She looks for others , but finds none .— and only mine ! Oh , father !...She wipes away tears from her eyes so as to see the picture , which is an old one .Father , I returned your love .She reads on the back of photograph .“ Blanche , my darling daughter , at fourteen years of age ! ” That 's mine ! that 's my own !And she puts the picture away separately . She takes up a small packet of very old love-letters tied with faded old pink tape .Old letters from mother ; they must be her love-letters . She shall have them ,— they may soften her .She takes up a slip of paper and reads on the outside .This is something for Mason , too .She puts it back in the case . She takes up a sealed envelope , blank .Nothing on it , and sealed .She looks at it a moment , thinking .Father , did you want this opened ? If you did n't , why not have destroyed it ? Ah ! I need n't be afraid ; you had nothing to hide from the world .Tearing it open , she reads .“ I have discovered my son-in-law , Richard Sterling , in irregular business dealing . He is not honest . I will watch him as long as I live ; but when you read this , Mason , keep your eye upon him for my daughter 's sake . He has been warned by me — he may never trip again , and her happiness lies in ignorance . ”She starts , and looks about her to make sure she is alone . She then sits staring ahead for a few seconds ; then she speaks .My boy 's father dishonest ! Disgrace — he owned it — threatening my boy ! It must n't come ! It must n't ! I 'll watch now .She goes to the fireplace , tearing the paper as she crosses the room , she burns the letter ; then she gathers up the other letters and the pocket case .He must give me his word of honor over Richard 's little bed to-night that he will do nothing to ever make the boy ashamed of bearing his father 's name !She watches to see that every piece of the paper burns , asTHE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: ACT II
