stage.stage: Christmas Eve ; fourteen months later ; the dining room of the Hunters ’ house , which is now lived in jointly by the STERLINGS and MRS. HUNTER and her daughters . It is a dark wainscoted room , with curtains of crimson brocade . It is decorated with laurel roping , mistletoe , and holly , for Christmas . It is the end of a successful dinner party , fourteen happy and more or less congenial persons being seated at a table , as follows : WARDEN , RUTH , MASON , CLARA , TROTTER , MRS. HUNTER , BLANCHE , STERLING , MISS SILLERTON , MR. GODESBY , JESSICA , DOCTOR STEINHART , and MISS GODESBY . The room is dark on all sides , only a subdued light being shed on the table by two large , full candelabra with red shaded candles . As the curtain rises the bare backs of the three women nearest the footlights gleam out white . Candied fruit and other sweetmeats are being passed by four men servants , including JORDAN and LEONARD .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: My dear Blanche , what delicious candy !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Is n't it !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Half of the candy offered one nowadays seems made of papier-mâché .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: To MISS GODESBY .Julia , do tell me how Mr. Tomlins takes his wife 's divorce ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: He takes it with a grain of salt !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: But is n't he going to bring a counter suit ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I hope not . I am an old-fashioned woman and do n't believe in divorce !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Really ! But then you 're not married !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: What is the reason for so much divorce nowadays ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Marriage is the principal one .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I do n't believe in divorce , either .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: My dear , no woman married to as handsome a man as Mr. Sterling would .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: You people are all out of date ! More people get divorced nowadays than get married .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Too many people do — that 's the trouble . I meant what I said when I was married — “ for better , for worse , till death us do part . ” — What is the opera Monday ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Something of Wagner 's . He 's a Dodo bird ! Bores me to death ! Not catchy enough music for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: You 'd adore him if you went to Bayreuth . Which was that opera , Clara , we heard at Bayreuth last summer ? Was it Faust or Lohengrin ! They play those two so much here I 'm always getting them mixed !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Wagner did n't write Faust !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Did n't he ? I thought he had ; he 's written so many operas the last few seasons !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I like Tannhäuser , because as soon as you hear the “ twinkle , twinkle , little stars ” song , you can cheer up and think of your wraps and fur boots .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: My favorite operas are San Toy and the Roger Brothers , though I saw Florodora thirty-six times !

lg.l: Mother would have gone with you every one of those thirty-six
Florodora times . She 's not really fond of music .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Not fond of music ! Did n't I have an opera box for four years ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Why does n't Conried make some arrangement with Weber and Fields and introduce their chorus into Faust and Carmen ?

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Great idea !To MISS GODESBY .Did you get a lot of jolly presents ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Not half bad , especially two fine French bulls !

div.stage: All are laughing and talking together .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: What did you get , Mr . Warden ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Three copies of “ David Harum , ” two umbrellas , and a cigar case too short for my cigars .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Give it to me for cigarettes .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: It 's too long for cigarettes . Then I had something that 's either a mouchoir or a handkerchief case , or for neckties , or shaving papers , or something or other .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Yes , I know , I got one of those , too .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: So did I !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I must start the women ; we are coming back here to arrange a surprise for you men .

div.stage: She nods her head in signal to STERLING , and rises . All rise .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: One moment please . One toast on Christmas night ! Ned , give us a toast .

sp.speaker: ALL THE WOMEN
sp.p: But not in unison .Oh , yes ! A toast !Ad lib .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Holding up his glass .Here 's to those whom we love ! And to those who love us ! And to those who love those whom we love And to those who love those who love us !

sp.speaker: ALL THE MEN
sp.p: Not in unison .Good ! Bravo ! Bully toast !Ad lib .

div.stage: Every one drinks .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: One more toast , Dick .To the others .Christmas Day is our boy 's birthday .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Surely ! a toast to Richard !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Long life to Master Sterling , the best boy in the world , and to all his good friends at this table .

sp.speaker: THE MEN
sp.p: Hear ! Hear !

div.stage: All the women speak their next speeches at the same time .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Laughing .Of course ! I 've dropped my handkerchief . } }NED dives under the table for it . } } MISS SILLERTON . O dear , my fan ! } } MISS GODESBY . What a bore ! I 've dropped a glove ! } } [ STEINHART goes under the table for it . } } CLARA . Both my gloves gone — I 'm so sorry ! } } [ GODESBY goes under the table for them . } } MRS. HUNTER . Dick , please , I 've dropped my smelling bottle . } [ ALL } togetherTROTTER and STERLING go under the table for it . } } RUTH . My gloves , please , I 'm so sorry ! } } [ MASON goes under the table for them . } } [ The speeches of the women are simultaneous , followed } by the movements of the men also , all at the same time . }

lg.l: Please do n't bother ; the servants —
LEONARD , JORDAN and , two extra men start to hunt under the table , too .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Women ought to have everything they own fastened to them with rubberneck elastics .

div.stage: The men , somewhat flustered , all rise with the various articles , and offer them to their respective owners .
All the women thank the men profusely , and apologize at the same time . STERLING takes MRS. HUNTER out at back , followed by all the other couples , all talking . RUTH and MASON lag behind .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: To BLANCHE , who with WARDEN waits for RUTH and MASON to pass .I want just a minute with Mr. Mason , Blanche .BLANCHE and WARDEN pass out before her . RUTH is alone with MASON . She speaks as if she were carrying on a conversation that had been interrupted . She speaks in a lowered voice , indicating the private nature of what she has to say .I sent him imperative word yesterday I must have the bonds . I told him I wanted one to give to his wife for Christmas . He pretends to-day he did n't receive this letter , but he must have .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: This makes the third time there has been some excuse for not giving you the bonds ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Yes , and this letter he says he did n't get was sent to his office by hand .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: I 'll speak to him before I leave .

div.stage: They go out at back .

As they pass out , JORDAN stands by the doorway holding the curtains back . The other three men stand stiffly at the Right . As MASON and RUTH go out , the SERVANTS relax and exchange glances , each giving a little laugh out loud , except JORDAN . During the following dialogue they empty the table preparatory to arranging the room for the Christmas tree .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Sh ! A very dull dinner , not an interesting word spoke .

sp.speaker: FIRST FOOTMAN
sp.p: The widder seemed chipper like !

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: And did you get on to the old lady 's rig-out ; mourning do n't hang very heavy on her shoulders .

div.stage: One chair is moved back .

lg.l: Get the coffee .
lg.stage: He goes out Right . To LEONARD .
lg.l: Get the smoking lay-out !

div.stage: LEONARD goes out Right and brings back a silver tray laden with cigarettes , cigar boxes , and a burning alcohol lamp .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: If you ask me , I think she 's going to put a bit more on the matrimonial mare if she gets the chance .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: It 's none of your business . You 're Mrs. Sterling 's servant now .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Good thing , too ; it was a happy day for us when they moved in .

sp.speaker: FIRST FOOTMAN
sp.p: Reënters with the coffee .Say , did you see how that young feller over thereMotioning to the lower right-hand corner of the table .shovelled the food in ?

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: And the way he poured down the liquid — regular hog ! My arm 's tired a-filling of his glass .

div.stage: And he drinks a glass of champagne which has been left untouched by a guest .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: He ai n't nobody ; he has n't any money ; he was just asked to fill up . He 's one of these yere singing chaps what 's asked to pass the time after dinner with a song or two gratis . This dinner 'll last him for food for a week ! Their manners suddenly change as the men reënter and take seats about the two ends of the table . STERLING , MASON , and DOCTOR down Left form one group . The other men are in a group between the window and the other end . On entering STERLING speaks .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Jordan , for heaven 's sake , give us something to see by ! You can n't tell which end of your cigar to light in this confounded woman 's candle-light . If I had my way , I 'd have candelabras made of Welsbachs !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Bright idea , Sterling .

div.stage: STERLING , laughing , joins his group , who laugh gently with him . JORDAN turns on the electric light . The servants pass the coffee , liqueurs , and the cigars and cigarettes . Meanwhile the following dialogue takes place , the men beginning to talk at once on their entrance .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Mr. Mason , I 'd like to ask your honest opinion on something if you 'll give it me .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: This Hudson Electric Company .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Oh ! Dropped fearfully to-day .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: But that can happen easily with the best thing . To-morrow —

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Interrupting .To-morrow it will drop to its very bottom !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I do n't believe it .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Surely , Mr. Mason , the men who floated that are too clever to ruin themselves ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: They 're out of it .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Out of it !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: They got out last week quietly .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Mark my words , the day after to-morrow there 'll be several foolish people ruined , and not one of the promoters of that company will lose a penny !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I do n't believe it !

div.stage: The crowd at the other end of the table , who have been listening to a tale from TROTTER , laugh heartily .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Delighted with his success .I 'm no Dodo bird !

div.stage: WARDEN leaves this group casually and joins the other .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: To STERLING .Do n't tell me you 're in it ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Ugly .Yes , I am in it !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Not much ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Yes , much !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Much what ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Oh , nothing ; we were just discussing stocks .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: And up there they 're discussing Jeffreys and Fitzsimmons .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Listen , Dick , after a lifelong experience in Wall Street , I defy any broker to produce one customer who can show a profit after three consecutive years of speculation .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Oh , you 're too conservative ; nothing venture , nothing have . Excuse me , I think Jeffreys and Fitzsimmons more amusing topics . Come along .

div.stage: STERLING and DR. STEINHART join the other group Right .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: To WARDEN .You 're Sterling 's broker .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No , not for over a year .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Then you can n't tell me how deep he is in this Hudson Electric swindle ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Is he in it at all ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Yes , he says , deep .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I suspected it yesterday .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: But what with — his wife 's money ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: That went fourteen months ago . I put him on his feet then , gave him some tips that enabled him to take this house with her mother , so that with his regular law business he ought to have done very well , but his living could not leave one cent over to speculate with .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: To himself .Good God !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I know what you 're afraid of .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Yes . The reason I 'm no longer his broker is he was ashamed to let me know about his dealings .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: But you do n't mean you think he 'd actually steal !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: His aunt 's money ? Why not ? He did his wife 's !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Does he handle any one else 's affairs ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I know he takes care of that Godesby woman 's property .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: And she would n't hold her tongue if a crash came !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Not for a minute ! Is Miss Hunter suspicious ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Yes . Does Sterling realize that to-morrow he will most probably be a ruined cheat ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Very likely .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: If he made up his mind to-night it was all up with him , he might do — what ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Run away with whatever money he has left , or kill himself . I do n't know if he 's enough of a coward for that or not . There 's one hold on him — he loves his wife .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Which will make him all the more ashamed of discovery . Do you believe she suspects ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Not a bit . She loves him too dearly .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Can we do anything ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Nothing but watch him closely till the people go . Then force him to make a clean breast of it , so we can all know where we stand ; how we can best protect his aunt from ruin and his wife and boy from public disgrace .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: He is watching us .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: He knows I know him ; we must be careful . He 's coming toward us .He then speaks in a different tone , but no louder .You 're certain of the trustworthiness of your information ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Absolutely . Every man left in that concern will be ruined before the ‘ Change closes after to-morrow .STERLING has joined them in time to hear the end of MASON 'S speech . MASON continues .I am telling Warden what I told you about the Hudson Electric Company .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Ca n't you talk of something pleasanter ?

div.stage: BLANCHE reënters at back . On her entrance all the men rise . The servants finish preparing the room for the tree .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I 'm very sorry — I really can n't let you men stay here any longer .

sp.speaker: ALL THE MEN
sp.p: Why not ? How 's that ?Ad lib .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: You know we want to get this room ready for Santa Claus ! Dick !She goes to her husband . All the men go out at back in a group led by WARDEN and MASON . They are all talking and laughing . BLANCHE is left alone with her husband .What is this Aunt Ruth has been telling me about not being able to get some bonds from you ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Oh , nothing . I forgot to send them up to her , that 's all .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: But she says she sent three times .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: One time too late to get into the vault ; and the other , her letter was mislaid — I mean not given to me .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: You have n't broken your word to me ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: What if I had ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I would let the law take its course .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: You must love me very little .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I live with you . First you robbed me of my respect for you ; then you dried up my heart with neglect .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: And our boy ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Your blood runs in his veins ; your shame and disgrace would be a fearful warning to him . It might kill me ; but never mind , if it saved him .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Oh , well , I have n't broken my word ! So you need n't worry . I 've been honest enough .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: With a long sigh of relief .Oh ! I hope so !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Appearing in doorway at back .The men are in the drawing-room — shall we come here ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Yes , we 'll bring the others , mother . Come , Dick .

div.stage: She goes out with MRS. HUNTER at back .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Goes to door Right , opens it , and calls .Leonard !

div.stage: LEONARD enters Right

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Yes , sir ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Go up to my library at the top of the house , get a railroad guide you will find there , and bring it down and put it on the table in the hall just outside the drawing-room door .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Then go to my room and pack my bag and dressing case . Do you understand ?

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: The women are heard singing “ Follow the Man from Cook 's , ” and gradually coming nearer .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Be quick , and say nothing to any one .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: He goes out quickly Right . STERLING goes up stage and stands beside the door at back as the women dance in , singing “ Follow the Man from Cook 's . ” They are led by CLARA , with MRS. HUNTER on the end . BLANCHE and RUTH follow alone , not dancing . The others dance around the chairs and CLARA jumps on and off one of them ; this stops the rest , who balk at it . STERLING goes out at back . The SERVANTS enter Right .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I do n't care for this dinner party at all . The women are all the time being chased away from the men ! I prefer being with Mr. Trotter . Do n't you , mama ?

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: He does n't seem able to give a dinner party any more without you to chaperone , Mrs. Hunter .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Mother , how can you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know as it 's chaperoning ! I like Mr. Trotter very much .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: But he 's such a little cad . I tried to give him a lift , but he was too heavy for me .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Oh , well , you ought just to pretend it 's the money in his pocket makes him so heavy ; then you 'd find him dead easy .

div.stage: Meanwhile the SERVANTS have arranged the table , taken out the extra leaves and made it square , and left the room . They now reënter , bringing in a gorgeously decorated and lighted Christmas tree . There is at once a loud chorus of delighted approval from the women . The SERVANTS place the tree in the centre of the table . The women who are sitting rise and come near to examine the tree .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: What a beautiful tree , Blanche !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: The boy is to have it to-morrow morning — it 's really his tree !TOMPSON brings in a large basket containing seven small stockings and six small boys ’ socks — very small stockings and very small socks . They are made of bright and different colors and are stuffed into absurd , bulgy shapes .There 's a name on each one . Come along now !

div.stage: Taking out a little sock . The women crowd around the basket and each hangs a sock on the tree , MISS GODESBY and CLARA standing on chairs .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Reading the name on her sock .Oh ! mine 's for Mr. Mason . What 's in it , Blanche ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I really can n't tell you . I asked the clerk where I bought it what it was for , and he said he did n't know ; it was a “ Christmas present . ”

lg.l: Oh , I know the kind ! Mine 's for Howard
Godesby . What 's his present ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: A silver golf marker .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: But he does n't play golf !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Well , he ought to ; it 'll keep him young .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: It will be all right , anyway , Julia ! You can give it away to some one next Christmas .

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: What 's in Mr. Trotter 's ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Oh , that present has almost been my death ! Men are so hard to find things for ! I had put in a gold pencil for his key chain , but to-night while we were eating our oysters , I saw him show a beauty that his mother had given him this morning ! So I whispered to Jordan between the soup and fish to change Mr. Ryder 's name to Mr. Trotter 's stocking , and put Mr. Trotter 's name on the one that had a cigarette case in it . I sneaked a message down to Dick on my dinner card — was it all right ?— and he sent back word during the game that Trotter only smoked cigars ; so before the ices were passed I shuffled Mr. Trotter 's and Mr. Mason 's names ,— I 'd given Mason the cigar case ,— and just as Jordan signalled to me the transfer had been successfully effected , I heard Trotter casually observe he 'd been obliged to give up smoking entirely — doctor 's orders !

div.stage: They laugh punctiliously , rather bored by BLANCHE 'S long account .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Is n't the tree stunning ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Getting down from her chair .It makes the table look like one of Mr. Trotter 's “ informal little dinners . ”

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: They say he has one of those men who arrange shop windows decorate his dinner table for him !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: The only time I ever dined with him I was really ashamed to go home with my dinner favor — it was so gorgeous ! And there were such big bunches of violets in the finger bowls there was n't room for your little finger .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: You never saw such a lot of decoration ! The game have ribbon garters on their legs , and even the raw oysters wear corsage bouquets !To MRS. HUNTER .I hope you do n't mind what we 're saying , Mrs. Hunter ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Offended .I must say I do mind very much .—A pause .— because —A second pause .— well , I am going to marry Mr. Trotter —All , not believing her , laugh merrily .You are all very rude !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Not on the level ! Not Trotter !

sp.speaker: MISS SILLERTON
sp.p: Not really !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No , no , of course not !

div.stage: She rings bell .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: But I am ! And I thought here at my daughter 's table , among my own friendsI was allowed to name the guests to-night, I could count on good wishes and congratulations .

div.stage: There is a dead silence .
The musicians , a band of Neapolitan players , enter and take their places in a recess at Left .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: To the musicians .You may play .To JORDAN , who has brought in the Neapolitans .We are ready , Jordan .

div.stage: JORDAN goes out at back .
RUTH goes to BLANCHE .
The guitars and mandolins begin a popular song .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: To MRS. HUNTER .Oh , well , Mrs. Hunter , we were only codding ! There 's lots of good in Trotter , and I 'm sure you 'll bring it out . Good luck !

div.stage: Shaking her hand .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: To BLANCHE , aside .You wo n't allow this !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Certainly not .BLANCHE crosses to her mother and they go to one side together ; BLANCHE speaks in a lowered voice .You 've amazed and shocked me ! I will not tolerate such a thing ; we 'll talk it over to-night .

div.stage: She leaves her and returns to her guests , MRS. HUNTER standing where she is left , biting her lips and almost crying with rage and mortification .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Before the musicians , to BLANCHE as she joins her .I 'm crazy about these men , Mrs. Sterling ; they play so awfully well — especially that one with the lovely legs !

div.stage: JORDAN pulls aside the curtains at back and all the men reënter except WARDEN . They all join hands and dance around the tree , singing with the musicians ; they break , and go up to a side table , where everything to drink is displayed . WARDEN enters at this moment and motions to MASON and leads him down stage .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: There was a railway guide in the hall — that 's what he went there for ; he 's going to run away to-night .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: How 'll we prevent it ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: First , we must break up this party !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I have n't quite thought yet . Go back to the others ; send Jordan to me ; do n't lose sight of Dick . Jordan !He takes him aside .I want you to go out of this room for a minute , pretend to go upstairs , then come back and tell Mrs. Sterling , loud enough for the others to hear you , that Master Richard is very ill , and say the maid is frightened .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Hesitating .But —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Quickly and firmly .Do as I tell you . I am responsible for whatever happens .

div.stage: JORDAN goes out at back . The men and women are laughing and talking about the sideboard .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Come now , everybody ! Let 's have the presents . Dick , you know you are to be Santa Claus .

div.stage: STERLING looks nervously at his watch .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Just a minute , dear ! Ned !Takes WARDEN to one side . The women move about the tree , hunting for their own names on the stockings on the table at the foot of the tree .Ned , I 've been suddenly called out of town on business — must catch the eleven-twenty train . I do n't want to break up the party , so you empty the tree , and when the time comes for me to go , I 'll slip out .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: And when your guests go ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Oh , then you can explain for me .

div.stage: JORDAN enters at back .

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: To BLANCHE .Beg pardon , madam , but Master Richard is very ill .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Alarmed .Richard !

sp.speaker: JORDAN
sp.p: Yes , ma'am , and Droves is very frightened , ma'am .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Richard ill ?

div.stage: All give exclamations of surprise and regret and sympathy .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: My little boy ill ? Excuse me , I must go to him .

div.stage: She hurries out at back . RUTH speaks to the musicians , who stop playing .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Moved .My boy ill — why , I can n't — I can n't —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: “ Ca n't ” what ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: How can I go away ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Surely you wo n't let business take you away from your boy who may be dying .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No ! I wo n't go ! I 'll face it out ! I can n't leave my boy like this —

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Coming to STERLING .I 'm going to take these women away ; tell Blanche not to give them a thought . Their evening up to now has been charming .

div.stage: During RUTH 'S speech , WARDEN has spoken aside with MASON .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Aside to MASON .Do n't let Miss Hunter go .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: To the other guests .Come to the drawing-room .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I was crazy to see what was in my stocking .

div.stage: All pass out talking , expressing conventional sympathy on account of RICHARD , but evidently resenting the breaking up of the party . STERLING and WARDEN are left alone in the room . STERLING moves to go up to back ; WARDEN interrupts him .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: To STERLING .Where are you going ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: To my boy and my wife .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Wait a minute ; I want to speak to you .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Speak to me later ; I can n't wait now .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Off stage , at back , excitedly .Jordan !She enters , excited , half hysterical .Jordan ! Where is Jordan ? It was a lie ! What did he mean ? Richard is sleeping sweetly . The maid knows nothing of being alarmed ! Where is Jordan ?

div.stage: She starts to go toward the door Right .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Stops her .Mrs. Sterling , he had nothing to do with it ! I told Jordan to say what he said .

div.stage: BLANCHE turns and looks at WARDEN in astonishment .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Stunned and at once suspicious .What ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Forgive me for so cruelly alarming you ; it was the only way I could think of for getting rid at once of your guests !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Angry .You 'll interfere once too often in the affairs of this house .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Indignant .But what excuse can you make , Mr . Warden ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Will you be so good as to ask Miss Hunter and Mr. Mason to come here ? They will explain what I have done , partly , and your husband will tell you the rest when you come back .

div.stage: STERLING sneers aloud .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I do n't understand , I do n't understand .

div.stage: She goes out at back .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Well , I do understand , at least enough .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Good ! That spares me a very disagreeable speech .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No , it does n't ! Come out with it ! What is it you want ? What is it you 've found out ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: From betraying a trust , you 've come , in less than two years , to an outright embezzlement .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Speak out — give us facts !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You 've stolen your aunt 's fortune .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Prove that !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: It 's her money that 's lost in the Hudson Electric Company ! STERLING . PROVE IT !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Easy enough , to-morrow .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: You 've got to excuse your action to-night or be kicked out of my house !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Strong .Is n't what I say the truth ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Equally strong .No ! And now get out !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Looks at his watch .I 'll not leave this house till it 's too late for you to take that eleven-twenty .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: More ugly .Yes , you will and mighty —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No , I 'll not !

div.stage: He is interrupted by the entrance of BLANCHE , RUTH , and MASON .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: To BLANCHE .I hope you forgive me now —

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Pathetically .You did right ; I thank you .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Heartbroken .Blanche — without hearing a word from me !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No , I 've come now to hear what you have to say .

div.stage: A deep-toned clock strikes eleven . STERLING , at the second stroke , takes out his watch with a hurried movement .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Quickly .Eleven o'clock .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I wish Warden to leave the room .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Firmly .And I wish him to stay .

div.stage: A short pause .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Well , of what am I accused ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Nobody wants to accuse you . We want you to make a clean breast of it .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Do n't you talk to me ; let my wife do the talking if you want me to answer .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Sit down , Aunt Ruth .RUTH sits by the table , WARDEN stands at back . STERLING stands at Right and BLANCHE and MASON sit near the centre .Aunt Ruth asks you to give her a true account of her trust in you . Mr. Mason is here as her friend and my father 's .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I have n't said I betrayed her trust . I told her she should have the bonds she wants to-morrow .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: But will she ? That 's what I want to know . I ask you if you have n't her bonds , to tell us here now ,— tell us , who have been and must be still the best friends , perhaps the only friends , you can have . Tell us where we all stand — are we the only ones to suffer or are there others who will perhaps be less generous in their treatment of you ? Tell us now while there is time perhaps to save us from public scandal , from the disgrace which would stamp your wife as the wife of a thief , and send your boy out into the world the son of a convict cheat .She breaks down , but in a moment controls herself . There is no answer . STERLING sinks into a chair , his arms on the table , his head on his arms . A moment 's silence .You love me — I know that . I appeal to your love ; let your love of me persuade you to do what I ask . I ask it for your sake and for mine ! Tell us here the truth now — it will spare me much to-morrow , perhaps — me whom you love — for love of me —

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: In an agony .I 'm afraid I 'll lose you —

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No , I 'll promise to stand by you if you 'll only tell us all the truth .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: In a low , shamed voice .I 'll tell you , but not now — not before all these others .

div.stage: BLANCHE looks up questioningly to MASON . MASON shakes his head .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: It must be now , Dick .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No ! no ! I can n't look you in the face and tell it ! Let me tell it to you alone , later , in the dark .

div.stage: BLANCHE looks up questioningly to MASON . He shakes his head .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: It must be now .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No , no , I 'm too ashamed , I can n't face you ; in the dark I 'll make a clean breast of it — let me tell you in the dark .

div.stage: WARDEN moves and puts his hand on the electric-light button beside the doorway at back .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: In the DARK , then , tell it !

div.stage: He presses the button and all the lights go out . The stage is in complete darkness ; only the voices are heard from the different places in which the actors are last seen .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Quickly .Remember , to help you to help ourselves , we must know everything . Go on .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: It began fourteen months ago , after Ned Warden put me on my feet ; I got a little ahead — why not get way ahead ? There were plenty of men around me making their fortunes ! I wanted to equal them — climb as high as they ; it seemed easy enough for them , and luck had begun to come my way . We 're all climbers of some sort in this world . I was a climber after wealth and everything it brings —

div.stage: He stops a moment .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Her voice comes throbbing with pathetic emotion through the darkness .And I after happiness and all it brings .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Deeply moved , his voice trembles for a moment , but only for a moment .Do n't , Blanche , or I can n't finish . Well , I borrowed on some of Aunt Ruth 's bonds and speculated — I made a hundred thousand in a week ! I put back the bonds . But it had been so easy ! I could see those bonds grinning at me through the iron side of the vault box . They seemed to smile and beckon , to beg me to take them out into the air again ! They grew to be like living things to me , servants of mine to get me gold — and finally I determined to make one bigger coup than ever ! I took Aunt Ruth 's bonds out and all the money available in my trust , and put it all into this new company ! It seemed so safe . I stood to be a prince among the richest ! And , for a day or so , I 've known nothing short of a miracle could save me from being wanted by the police ! To-night I gave up even the miracle . That 's all . It 's no use saying I 'm sorry .

div.stage: A moment 's pause .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Have others suffered besides Miss Hunter ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: There is some money of Aunt Ruth 's left — stock I could n't transfer . But I used the money of others — Miss Godesby and Ryder 's .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Miss Ruth , a large part of your fortune is gone , used unlawfully by this man . Will you resort to the law ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Very quietly .No !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: In a voice broken with emotion and gratitude .Aunt Ruth !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: We can n't hope Miss Godesby and Ryder will be as lenient ! You must go to them in the morning — tell them everything , put yourself at their mercy , ask for time and their silence .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Never ! I could n't do it .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: It is the only honorable way out of your dishonorable action — the least you can do !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Confess to their faces , and probably to no good ? Eat the dust at their feet , and most likely be clapped into prison for it ? No , thank you !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Suppose I went to them ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: You ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: No ! Why should you !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Yes ! Why not ? They might keep silent for her !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I would do it for my boy 's sake . Yes , I 'll go .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Yes ! You go , Blanche .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: No , you sha n't go — you sha n't humiliate yourself in his place !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Certainly not ; and if your husband is willing , we are not willing ! He must go .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: But if he wo n't ?

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: He must !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: You must demand his going , Blanche , and I demand it , too , as something due to me .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Very well . I demand it . Will you go ?

div.stage: A moment 's silence .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Why do n't you speak ?He presses the electric button and all the lights come on . STERLING is at the doorway at back , about to steal out . There is an exclamation aloud from all of surprise and disgust . The clock strikes the quarter ; WARDEN catches hold of STERLING 'S arm .What 's your hurry , Dick ? There goes the quarter hour ; you could never catch the eleven-twenty .

lg.l: Damn you !
THE CURTAIN FALLS QUICKLY

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: At “ The Hermitage , ” on the Bronx River , the next afternoon . The house is on the Left , and on the Right and at the back are the green lattice arches . Snow lies thick everywhere , on the benches at the Right and on the little iron table beside it , on the swing between two trees at the Right , in the red boxes of dead shrubs , on the rocks and dried grass of a “ rookery ” in the centre , and on the branches of the trees . CLARA comes out from the house , followed by TROTTER .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Come on and let mama rest awhile — naturally she 's excited and tired out , being married so suddenly and away from home .She stops beside the swing , taking hold of its side rope with her hand .It is n't every mother who can elope without her oldest child 's consent and have her youngest daughter for a bridesmaid .

div.stage: Laughing .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I hope Mrs. Sterling will forgive me . Perhaps she will when she sees how my money can help your mother and me to get right in with all the smarties !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Oh , do n't you be too sure about your getting in ; it is n't as easy as the papers say ! But , anyway , that would n't make any difference to Blanche . She was never a climber like mama and me . I suppose that 's why she is asked to all sorts of houses through Aunt Ruth that would n't let mama and me even leave our cards on the butler !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I thought your mother could go anywhere she liked .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Oh , no , she could n't ! if she made you think that , it was only a jolly ! Blanche is the only one of us who really went everywhere . Come along , “ Poppa , ” give me a swing ! I have n't had one for years !

div.stage: She sweeps off the snow from the seat of the swing with her hand .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Your mother certainly did represent —

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Sitting in the swing .Oh , well , now do n't blame mama ! She could n't help herself ; she always thought you dreadfully handsome ! Swing me !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I do n't care , anyway . I 'm deucedly proud of your mother ,— I mean of my wife ,— and I 'd just as lief throw up the whole society business and go off and live happily by ourselves .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: O dear ! I think mama would find that awfully dull . Go on , swing me !TROTTER swings her .Of course , you 'll find mama a little different when you see her all the time . You really wo n't see much more of her , though , than you do now . She does n't get up till noon , and has her masseuse for an hour every morning , her manicure and her mental science visitor every other day , and her face steamed three times a week ! She has to lie down a lot , too , but you must n't mind that ; you must remember she is n't our age !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Swings her .She suits me !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: That 's just what I feel ! You 'll take care of her , and me , too , all our lives , and that 's what makes me so happy . I 'm full of plans ! We 'll go abroad soon and stay two years .He has stopped swinging her .Go on , swing me !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Holding the swing still .Say ! if you think you are going to run me and the whole family , you 're a Dodo bird ! Remember that you 're my daughter ; you must wait a little if you want to be a mother-in-law .

div.stage: Sleigh-bells are heard in the distance , coming nearer .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Good gracious ! If you ask me , I think mama has got her hands full . What 's become of Miss Godesby and her brother ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: When you went upstairs with your mother , they went down the road .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: You know originally the idea was I was to marry you .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Really —

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Laughingly .Yes , and mama cut me out .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Oh , well , it can n't be helped ; we can n't marry everybody .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Noticing the bells .Somebody else arriving ! That 's queer — nobody comes here in the winter ; that 's why we chose it , because it would be quiet ! Let 's play this game .

div.stage: Going to an iron frog on a box which stands near the house .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Perhaps it 's Mrs. Sterling .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: No ; if she was coming at all , she 'd have come in time for the wedding .She takes up the disks which lie beside the frog .I should hate to get married like you and mama — no splurge and no presents ! Why , the presents 'd be half the fun ! And think of all those you and she 've given in your life , and have lost now a good chance of getting back .

div.stage: Throws a disk into the frog 's open mouth .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I 'll give your mother all the presents she wants . I can afford it ; I do n't want anybody to give us anything !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: You talk like Jess !Throws another disk .You know Jess earns her own living . She goes around to smart women 's houses answering their invitations and letters for ‘ em . She calls it being a visiting secretary , but I tell her she 's a co-respon-dent !

div.stage: Throws a disk .
WARDEN and MASON enter from behind the house quickly , with a manner of suppressed excitement . They are surprised to find CLARA and TROTTER .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Why , here they are !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: No , only Miss Clara and Trotter .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Lucky I met you — you must take me back in your sleigh .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Yes , the riding 's beastly .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Hello ! I say , were you invited ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Merry Christmas !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: We came to see the Godesbys .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: They 've gone down the road .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Sterling is n't here , is he ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: No , have n't seen him .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Do you know why we 're here ?

div.stage: MASON and WARDEN are embarrassed .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Yes — er — er — a — many happy returns , Mr. Trotter .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: It 's a great day for me , Mr. Mason !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Wish you joy , Trotter !

div.stage: Embarrassed and not going near him . TROTTER rushes eagerly to him and grasps his hand warmly .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Thank you , old man ! I say ! Thank you !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Miss Clara , would you do me the great favor of going down the road and hurrying the Godesbys back if you see them ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Yes , I do n't mind ; come along , Trotty !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You must excuse Trotter . I want a talk with him if he will give me five minutes .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Oh , certainly .

div.stage: She goes out Left behind the house .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: To MASON .Will you see Mrs. Hunter ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I beg your pardon , Mrs. Trotter !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Politely .I beg yours .To MASON .See Mrs. Trotter .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Aside to WARDEN .You 're going to ask him to go on Dick 's note for Ryder ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: In a low voice .Yes .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: You 're a wonder ! As if he would !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Somebody must , and there 's nobody else . That boy and that mother have got to be saved !

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: I 'm sorry my name 's no good for us .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: And mine must n't be used .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: No , indeed ! The minute that was done , there 'd be a new complication , and more trouble would tumble down on Mrs. Sterling 's head . Good luck .

div.stage: Shakes his hand and enters the house .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: What 's up ? You have n't come to kick about my wedding , have you ? I would n't stand for that , you know !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: It 's not that , Mr. Trotter . Your wife 's son-in-law , Sterling , has turned out a blackguard ; he has had intrusted to him Miss Ruth Hunter 's money and several other people 's , and he 's used it all for speculation of his own .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Then he 's a damned thief !

div.stage: He sits on the bench with the manner that he has settled the subject .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: So he is , and he 's ruined .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Well , prison is the place for him .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: We wo n't argue that , but how about his family — they get punished for what he has done ; they must share his disgrace .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Oh , well , my wife is out of all that now — she 's Mrs. Trotter .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Yes , but her own daughter suffers .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: On the defensive .She is n't very chummy with her classy eldest daughter .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Never mind that ; you know without my telling you that Mrs. Sterling is a fine woman .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: She 's always snubbed me right and left , but , by George , I must own she is a fine woman .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: That 's right !Clapping him on the back and putting his arm around his shoulder .Look here — help us save her !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: How ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Indorse a note of Sterling 's to give Ryder to keep him quiet .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: I 'd have to ask my wife .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No ! Do n't start off like that ! Keep the reins in your own hands at the very beginning ,— make her realize from this very day that you 're raised up on the cushion beside her ; that she 's sitting lower down admiring the scenery , while you do the driving through life !

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Half laughing .Ha ! I guess you 're right . Box seat and reins are good enough for me !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Good boy ! Then we can count on you to sign this note ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Where 's my security ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I can get you security if you want it .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Of course I want it ! And I say , where are you ? Why are n't you in it ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: There are reasons why my name had better not appear ; you are in the family . But I 'll tell you what I 'll do , Trotter ; I 'll secure you with a note of my own — only you must keep it dark ; you must n't even let Mason know .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: All right , perhaps I 'm a Dodo bird , but I 'll do it . Say , I seem to have married a good many of this classy family !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Trotter , no one 's done you justice ! And , by George ! you deserve a better fate — er — I mean — my best wishes on your wedding day .

div.stage: TROTTER shakes his hand delightedly .

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Great day for me ! What I wanted was style and position , and some one classy who would know how to spend my money for me !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Well , you 've got that , surely !

div.stage: CLARA comes back from the house .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: The Godesbys are coming . Trotter , there 's skating on the river near here , and they 've skates in the house — do n't you want a spin ?

sp.speaker: TROTTER
sp.p: Yes , I do n't mind — if my wife does n't need me !CLARA laughs as GODESBY and MISS GODESBY enter from behind the house . TROTTER meets them , with CLARA on his arm .Excuse us for a little while !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Poppa and I 're going skating !

div.stage: They go out Left .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Hello , Warden .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Good morning , Miss Godesby .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Good morning .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: How are you , Godesby ? I 've come on a matter most serious , most urgent — something very painful .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: What is it ?

div.stage: Comes forward .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Both of you trusted Dick Sterling .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: What 's he done ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Misused your funds .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: How d'you mean ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I mean that the money you intrusted to him is gone , and I 've come to make a proposition to you .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Gone ?

div.stage: GODESBY and MISS GODESBY are aghast . A second 's silence , during which GODESBY and MISS GODESBY look at each other , then back at WARDEN .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Do you mean to say —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: The money is gone , every penny of it , and I want you to accept a note from Sterling to cover the amount .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I can n't grasp it !

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Where is Sterling ? Why did n't he come ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: He was ashamed .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: I should hope so !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Several of us are going to stick by him ; we 'll manage to put him on his feet again , and we want you to accept his note .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Incredulous .Accept his note ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Also incredulous .On what security ?

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Quickly .You 'll do nothing of the sort , Julia !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I 'll see him where he belongs , in State 's Prison , first !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: That would n't bring you back your money .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Neither will his note !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: If I get it indorsed ?

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Likely !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Rather !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I want your silence to keep it from the public for the family 's sake . I 've secured a satisfactory indorser for a note to satisfy Ryder 's claim .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Why did n't you give him to me instead of Ryder ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I felt you would be willing , out of friendship —

div.stage: There are sleigh-bells in the distance , coming nearer .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Huh ! you must take me for an idiot !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Out of friendship for his wife .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Blanche Sterling ! I never could bear her ! She 's always treated me like the dirt under her feet !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You dined with her last night .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: That was to please her mother . No , if my money 's gone , Sterling 's got to suffer , and the one slight consolation I shall have will be that Blanche Sterling will have to come off her high horse .

div.stage: The sleigh-bells stop .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: To MISS GODESBY .Ten to one if you agree to sign this note —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: And keep silent .

lg.l: Oh , yes , of course , the next morning when
I wake up Sterling will be gone ! Nobody knows where !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I 've had it out with Sterling ! I am here as his representative . I give you my word of honor Sterling will not run away . It is under such an understanding with him that I am pleading his case in his stead . He will stay here and work till he has paid you back , every cent .

div.stage: JESSICA enters hurriedly from the house .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: In great excitement .Mr . Warden , Mr . Warden , Dick has gone !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Sterling ? Gone ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Gone ?

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: That 's good !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Do n't be a fool , Godesby . How do you mean “ gone , ” Miss Hunter ?

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: I do n't altogether know . While I was out this morning , Blanche received a message from mother saying she 'd been —

div.stage: She hesitates , looking toward GODESBY and MISS GODESBY .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: They know . They 're your mother 's guests here .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: She told Blanche they would be glad to have her here at one o'clock for breakfast . Blanche ordered the sleigh at once and went away , leaving word for me I was to open any message which might come for her .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: To GODESBY .Has she been here ?

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Not that I know of .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Eager to hear more .No , no !

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: No , they say not . She probably went first to Aunt Ruth 's . Before I got back , Dick , who 'd been out —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: He was at my house .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Yes . He came back , questioned Jordan as to where Blanche was , went upstairs , and then went away again , leaving a note for Blanche , which I found when I came home —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Eagerly .Yes ?

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: It simply said , “ Good-by . Dick . ”

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Very angry .Oh !

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Quickly .He 's taken a train ! He 's cleared out !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Do you know if he took a bag or anything with him ?

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: No , he took nothing of that sort . Jordan went into his room and found a drawer open and empty , a drawer in which Dick kept — a pistol !—

div.stage: She drops her voice almost to a whisper .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Good God , he 's shot himself !

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Perhaps not — he left the house .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Yes , if he were really determined to shoot himself , why would n't he have done it there in his own room ?

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: What can we do ? What can we do ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I 'll get Mr. Mason ; he 's with your mother ; he must go back to town at once .

div.stage: Going to the house .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: He can go with me ; I 'd better be at the house . Some one must be there .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Good !

div.stage: He goes into the house .
MISS GODESBY and her brother ignore and apparently forget the presence of JESSICA in their excitement . They both speak and move excitedly .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I ought to have suspected something when Sterling told me he was getting ten per cent for my money ,— the blackguard !

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: I always told you you were a fool not to take care of your money yourself ! You know more about business than most men .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I did n't want to be bothered ; besides , there was always something very attractive about Sterling . I do n't mind telling you that if he had fallen in love with me instead of the stiff-necked woman he married , I 'd have tumbled over myself to get him .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: How do you feel about him now ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Now ! Thank God , I 'm saved such a waking up ! It 's going to make a big difference with my income , Howard ! I wonder if his wife knew he was crooked ! I 'll bet you she 's got a pot of money stowed away all right in her own name .

sp.speaker: JESSICA
sp.p: Who can bear no more , interrupts .Please — please ! Remember that you 're speaking of my sister and that every word you are saying cuts through me like a knife .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I beg your pardon ; I ought to have thought . I like and respect you , Jess , and I 've been very rude .

lg.l: You 've been more than that ; you 've been cruelly unjust to
Blanche in all that you 've said !
Perhaps I have , but I do n't feel in a very generous mood ;
I 've some excuse — so please forgive me .

div.stage: WARDEN reënters Left .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: To JESSICA .Mason is waiting for you with the sleigh . He 's going first to my house . Dick may have gone back there to hear the result of my interview with Ryder ,— then Mason 'll try his own house and Sterling 's club .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: The police are the best men to find Sterling , whatever 's happened .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: To GODESBY .You wait a minute with me ; I have n't finished with you yet .To JESSICA .I 'll stay here for your sister , in case she comes .

div.stage: JESSICA goes out Left .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: To MISS GODESBY .Do n't you give in !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Not for a minute !To WARDEN .Do n't you think , under the circumstances , the wedding breakfast had better be called off , and my brother and I go back to town ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Not till you 've given me your promise , both of you , that you will keep silent about the embezzlement of your bonds for the sake of Mrs. Sterling and her son .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Half laughs .Huh !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: For the sake of her mother , who is your friend .

div.stage: Sleigh-bells start up loud and die off quickly ; JESSICA has gone .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh , come , you know what sort of friends we are ,— for the amusement we can get out of each other . This is the case ,— I trusted this man with my affairs . He was very attractive — I do n't deny that ; business with Dick Sterling became more or less of a pleasure — but that does n't cut any ice with me ; he 's stolen my money . To put it plainly , he 's a common thief , and he ought to be punished ; why should he go scot free and a lot of others not ? You know perfectly well his note would n't be worth the paper it was written on ; and , anyway , if he has n't gone and sneaked out of the world , I wo n't lift my little finger to keep him from the punishment he deserves !

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Good for you , Julia !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Do n't you put your oar in , Godesby ; just let this matter rest between your sister and me ! She 's always been known as the best man in your family .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: You do n't choose a very conciliatory way of bringing us around !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I 'm not choosing any way at all ; I 'm striking right out from the shoulder . There is n't time for beating round the bush ! I 'm pleading for the good name and honorable position of a perfectly innocent , a fine , woman , and for the reputation and unimpeded career of her son ! And I make that appeal as man to man and woman !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I have nothing to do with any one in this matter but Sterling himself , who has robbed me , and I 'll gladly see him suffer for it !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Now look here , Miss Godesby , you belong to a pretty tough crowd in society , but I know at heart you 're not a bad sort ! What good will it do you ? Granted even that you do n't care for Mrs. Sterling , still do n't tell me you 're the kind of woman to take a cruel pleasure in seeing another woman suffer ! I would n't believe it ! You 're not one of those catty creatures ! You 're a clever woman , and I do n't doubt you can be a pretty hard one , too , at times ; but you 're just — that 's the point now — you 're JUST —

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Interrupting .Exactly ! I 'm just , an eye for an eye ! Sterling is a thief , let him get the deserts of one !

div.stage: She sits on the bench determinedly .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: But you can n't look at only one side ! You can n't shut your eyes to his wife 's suffering , too , and she does n't deserve it ! Neither does her boy deserve to share his disgrace .He sits beside her .Why , you have it in your power to handicap that boy through his whole life by publishing his father a criminal ; or you can give that boy a fair show to prove himself more his mother 's son than his father 's , and to live an honest — who knows — perhaps a noble life !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I refuse to accept such a responsibility . Ryder —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Rises , interrupting her .Ryder 's word is given to be silent .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Well , that 's his lookout .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You 'll have many a heart wrench , I 'll bet you ! You 'll have to run across the results of the harm you do to Mrs. Sterling and Richard day in and day out , year after year ! I do n't believe you realize what it means ! Why , I know you can n't bear to see a dog suffer ! I met you last week on the street carrying a mangy , crippled brute of a little dog in your arms , afraid lest he 'd get into the hands of the vivisectionists , and yet here you 'll let a boy and his mother —

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Interrupts him , struggling against a tiny emotion which he has stirred .Stop Stop ! I do n't want you working on my feelings that way .

div.stage: She rises and turns from him

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Follows her .I 'm only knocking at the door of your heart . And now because it 's opened just a tiny way , you want to shut it in my face again . Will you leave this woman 's name fit for her to use ? Wo n't you make that boy 's life worth living to him ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: After a moment 's pause , looks straight into WARDEN 'S face .I 'll tell you what I 'll do . Get me some security , some sort of indorsement of Sterling 's note —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: If the man 's only alive !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: And I 'll hold my tongue .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: How long will you give me ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh , come , I can n't have any monkey business ! You must get me my security to-day .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: To-day ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: That 's my last word .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Stick to that , Julia !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I sha n't try to persuade her against that . Will you leave your sister alone with me a moment . Perhaps you 'll see about your sleigh being ready to return to town .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: I 've no objection — if Julia wishes it .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Yes , go on , Howard !

div.stage: GODESBY goes out back of house .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Left alone with MISS GODESBY , goes nearer to her .Look , here ! Will you accept my indorsement ? Will I be all right ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Incredulously .Certainly .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Then it 's settled ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: You do n't mean it !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I do .

lg.l: You 'd be willing to lose —
Oh — for Mrs. Sterling ! I see !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Very seriously .I would n't . I would n't see .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: And she 's always been blackguarding me for my affairs with men ! And all the time —

lg.l: Do n't say any more , please , Miss
Godesby ! I only wish your brother had said that much instead of you .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Disagreeably .So you 're in love with Blanche Sterling ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh , come , do n't tell a lie about it ; that will only make it seem worse .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Well , suppose I were in love with her — what of it ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Nothing ; only , my dear Warden , that woman —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Interrupts .Wait a minute ! You 've got me in a corner , but knowing half the truth , you must n't guess the whole . She is even more ignorant of my love for her than you were ten minutes ago !MISS GODESBY smiles and makes a little satirical exclamation .You do n't believe that , but I 'll make you . I 'm going to tell you something I 've never even told myself . I 'm going to put you to a big test , because I 've got to . Apparently , I can n't help myself ; but after all , somehow I believe in the human nature in you , and you 've got it in your power to help or hurt the woman I love — I say those words aloud for the first time — the woman I love !

div.stage: He has finished his speech in a lowered tone throbbing with controlled feeling .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Incredulously .You 've never told her ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Never ; and you show how little you really know her when you ask that question ! She loves her husband .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I 'm not so sure about that !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I am , and I love her . But surely the silent love of a man , like mine , is no insult to a good woman — cannot harm her ! A love that is never spoken , not even whispered , can n't hurt any one , except , perhaps , the one who loves . You must acknowledge even you have never heard a hint ; you showed just now your real surprise at what circumstances revealed to you ! I 'd die sooner than bring the slightest shadow of a scandal on her , and I 've hugged my secret tight . Have you any idea what such a love means ? How it grows and grows , its strength shut in , held back , doubling and redoubling its powers !— its ideality increasing , the passion suppressed , locked up ! Good God ! I tremble sometimes when I think — suppose some day it should burst out , break my control , MASTER ME !A pause .And here , now , I 've told you ; I 'm sorry , but I had to for her sake again . Will you help me keep my secret ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: After a second 's pause .Yes , because I believe you .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: And Mrs. Sterling ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Slowly , with sincere meaning .I envy her !

div.stage: Her voice breaks and she turns away from him .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No one is to know I indorse Sterling 's note ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: You need n't sign the note ; my brother 'd have to see it . I 'll take your word for the indorsement .

div.stage: She offers him her hand . They shake hands .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: What a brick you are ! You know you do n't do yourself anything like justice in the world !

div.stage: GODESBY reënters Left and after him a MAN SERVANT in ordinary clothes , who passes through the archway at back Centre .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Ready !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Aside to her .You can promise his silence about Sterling ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh , yes , he 's absolutely dependent upon me .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: To NED with a forced gaiety .Good-by !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Again shaking her handGood-by .

div.stage: He looks his thanks at her .

sp.speaker: GODESBY
sp.p: Well ? What did you do ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: As they go .Do n't worry ; I 've taken care of myself for many years , and I still feel up to it !They go out Left and at the same time the SERVANT enters from the archway at back Centre carrying some fire logs in his arms . This SERVANT speaks with a slight French accent . As he reaches the house , WARDEN stops him with a question , and the GODESBYS ’ sleigh-bells start up and quickly die away . The sun begins to set .WARDEN Have you an empty sitting room ?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Yes , sair . WARDEN Warm ?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: I will soon arrange a fire . WARDEN I wish you would , please .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Ze big room for ze breakfast is altogether ready and warm ; you will be able to go in there now .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No , that would n't do . It 's all right out here for me , only I am expecting a lady .

div.stage: Sleigh-bells are heard in the distance , coming quickly nearer .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Yes , sair .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I hear a sleigh coming . If a lady is in it , ask if her name is Mrs. Sterling , and if she says yes , tell her Mr . Warden is here and would like to speak with her a moment before she goes in to Mrs .—

div.stage: He hesitates a second .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Trottair ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Yes , sair .

div.stage: He goes into the house .
The sun grows red , and the colors of sunset creep over the sky during the scene which follows . After a moment the SERVANT shows BLANCHE out from the house .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Surprised and depressed .Good morning , Mr . Warden , have you been asked to these funeral baked meats ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No , I 'll explain why I am here in a few minutes . Only let me ask you first when you last saw your husband ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Early this morning .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: And you have come just now from where ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Aunt Ruth 's . Of course you know about my mother ? When I heard it I started to come here , but my heart failed me and I turned back to my aunt 's . She has persuaded me that I ought to come and put the best face on the matter possible , but it seems as if I 'd had now a little more than I can bear !

div.stage: Her voice breaks and her eyes fill with tears .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Almost tenderly .Shall we go inside ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No , no ! Let us stay out in the air ; my head would burst in one of these close little rooms . Have you seen mother ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No , not yet .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Where is Dick ? Did he go to Ryder 's ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No , but I have some good news to tell you all the same — Ryder has promised silence .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: With tremendous relief .Oh ! that 's too good , too good to be true ! To whom did he promise ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I want you not to ask me that .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I can guess , it was —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Lying .No , it was — Mason .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Doubting him .Mr. Mason ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: And I 've more good news for you , Mrs. Sterling — the Godesbys , too ; they will be silent .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: You 're sure ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: We have their word !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Pointedly .Mr. Mason again ?—

div.stage: WARDEN bows his head in assent . ] He was here ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Some time ago , but only for a minute . He did n't stay ; he went to find your husband .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: But the Godesbys ? I just met them now on the road going back . How could Mr. Mason , if he did n't stay —WARDEN is embarrassed , and is silent , searching a way out of it .Oh , no ! no ! it was n't Mr. Mason ! I see the whole thing clearly . Dick was too great a coward , and you did it ! It was you who won over Ryder ! It was you who persuaded the Godesbys !—

div.stage: WARDEN shakes his head and makes a movement to deny it . BLANCHE continues speaking , the words rushing to her lips , as her pent-up heart opens and lets all her emotions suddenly free . ] Do n't try to deny it ; you can n't make me believe you ! It 's to you I owe whatever promise the future has for me ! It is you who have given me all the happiness I 've had for years . It is you who have watched over , taken care of , me — you , the best friend any woman in this world ever had . It is you now who have saved my boy 's honor . It is you who lift the weight off my shoulders , the weight off my heart ! You !— you !— you !
She sinks sobbing on the bench . It begins to snow very quietly and slowly .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: All his love bursting out into his face and into his voice , cries .Blanche ! Blanche !

div.stage: Leaning over her as if to protect her from her trouble and take her to his breast .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Rising and looking straight into his eyes with a suddenly revealed great love in her own .Ned !—

div.stage: They hold this position some moments , gazing into each other 's eyes ; then finally WARDEN makes a movement towards her , crying out more triumphantly , having read and realized her love for him .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Blanche !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Moving a half step back from him .No —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: No ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Look — look , it 's beginning to snow !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Very softly .What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Desperately .I mean to speak of anything except what is in your thoughts at this moment ! Help me not to forget that no matter what he has done , Dick is still my husband .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You do n't know all he has done !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: How not “ all ” ? What else ? Where is he ?

div.stage: With a sudden new alarm .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: He has left you .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Echoes .Left me ?—

lg.l: Mason is searching for him . He left a note at your house which
Jess read ; it was only one word “ Good-by . ”

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Echoes again .Good-by !Sleigh-bells are heard in the distance , coming quickly nearer .What does it mean ? You 're hiding something from me ! Tell me what else you know ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: He left the house , but took something with him — something from a drawer in his room .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: After a second 's pause she whispers .His pistol ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Aghast , still whispers .Has he done it ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I do n't know ; I 'm waiting word from Mason .

div.stage: The sleigh-bells stop .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Excited .But we can n't wait here doing nothing ; we must go , too !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Mason is doing all that can be done ; we 'd better wait here .

div.stage: He takes her hand in sympathy , but without suggesting the passion of a few moments before . STERLING enters hurriedly Left . He is wild with drink and jealousy .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Drop my wife 's hand !

div.stage: They turn in great surprise .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Dick !

div.stage: Fright at his appearance is mingled with her surprise .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: At the same time as BLANCHE .Sterling !

div.stage: They do not drop hands .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Coming nearer , very strong .Drop my wife 's hand !They do so quickly , not understanding yet .So I 've caught you !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Angry .Caught us !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Yes , I had my suspicions roused some time ago !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Of what ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I could go to the devil — what did you two care ! I could go to State 's Prison ! All the better — out of your way !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You 're speaking like a madman !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I went back to my house this morning ; my wife was gone — no message left where to ! But I questioned the servant . She 'd driven here ! Why ? Ha !A bitter half laugh ; he turns to BLANCHE .You 've come here once too often !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Very strong .Sterling !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: To WARDEN , but ignoring his exclamation .Then I went to your house . They knew where you 'd gone ! You ought to train your servants better ! Both here !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: If you 're not careful , I 'll ram your insinuations down your throat .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Jeers .“ Insinuations ? ” I 've caught you ! I make no “ insinuations . ” I tell you both you 're caught ! You 're my wife 's lover , and she 's your damned mis —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Seizing STERLING by the throat .Do n't you finish !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Sh !— for Heaven 's sake !To WARDEN .Let him alone ; I 'm not afraid of what he says .

div.stage: WARDEN leaves STERLING .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No , you never were a liar , I 'll give you credit for that ,— so confess the truth — you 're his —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Excited beyond her control .Listen ! And you shall have the truth if you want it ! These years that he 's been befriending me I never dreamed of loving him nor thought of his loving me .DICK sneers .Wait ! No , not even the day my father was buried , when I learned outright you were dishonest !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Surprised .What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: What I say — I learned it then from a paper of my father 's . I should n't have kept my knowledge to myself — I see that now ; but I did , for your sake , not for love of you — the love went for good that day . But here , a moment ago , I realized for the first time that my old friend did love me , love me with an ideal devotion the noblest woman in the world might be proud of ! I did n't tell him then I loved him , but now I take this chance , I take it GLADLY before you !— forced by you ! I tell him now , what perhaps he has already guessed , I love him with all my heart — I love him ! I LOVE HIM !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Damn you both ! then it 's the end of me !

div.stage: He pulls out a pistol and tries to put it to his temple .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Cries out .Ned !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Seizes STERLING , catches his arm , and wrenches the pistol from him .So that 's what you planned to do , is it — make a wretched scene like that ?

div.stage: It begins to snow more heavily .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: In utter collapse and shame .Why did you stop me ? I 'm better out of the world . I 'm crazy with shame . First I disgraced and now I 've insulted — degraded — the only living thing I care for ,— that 's my wife .

div.stage: A moment 's pause .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Speaks quietly .Come back to the house . Mr. Mason is looking for you ; he has something to tell you .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I know — more bad news .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No , good .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Echoes .Good !Starting to go , he turns at the porch .I want you to know that I know I 'm a rotten beast .

div.stage: He goes out Left .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You 're going back home ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: “ Home ! ”With a faint smile .I should hardly call it that .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Aside to her .You 're not afraid ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Half smiling .Oh , no ! And my boy 's there .

div.stage: The thick falling snow almost hides them , but they are unconscious of it .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: What 's to be done ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Wait ; we 'll see — we 'll see — let it be something we could never regret . Good-by , Ned .

div.stage: Giving him her hand .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Good-by , Blanche .Kissing her hand very tenderly and almost with a certain kind of awe , asTHE CURTAIN SLOWLY FALLS

div.head: ACT IV

stage.stage: The following morning ; at the STERLINGS ’ ; the library ; a warm , livable , and lovable room , full of pictures , photographs , and books ; mistletoe and holly decorate everywhere .
