In the bow-window at back there is a large bird-cage with half a dozen birds in it . The furniture is comfortable and heavily upholstered . At Left there is a fireplace with logs ready , but the fire is not lit . There a big table near the centre , full of magazines , illustrated papers , and books . A big arm-chair is beside the table , and other chairs conversationally close . There is a table near the door at Right , piled with Christmas gifts , still wrapped in white paper ; they are tied with many colored ribbons and bunches of holly . There are doors Right and Left . After the curtain rises on an empty stage , RUTH enters quickly ; while she has her buoyant manner , she is , of course , more serious than usual . She carries a bunch of fresh violets in her hand . She looks about the room with a sort of curiosity . She is waiting for some one to appear . She takes up a silver-framed photograph of her brother which stands on a table and speaks aloud to it .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I 'm glad you 're spared this .With a long-drawn breath she places the photograph back upon the table and turns to greet BLANCHE , who comes in Right .Good morning , my dear .

div.stage: She kisses her .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Good morning . You 've had my note ?RUTH nods .Thank you . I wanted to see you before I saw any one else . You must help me decide , only you can .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Have you seen your husband this morning ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No . He sent word he was feeling ill , but would like to see me when I was willing .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: And you ?

div.stage: They sit near each other .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I do n't want to talk with him till I see more clearly what I am going to do .

lg.l: Mr . Warden told me last night all that happened at “ The
Hermitage . ” But on your ride home with Dick ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: We never spoke .She rises .Aunt Ruth , I am going to leave him .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Rising .No !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Walking up and down .Why not ? Everybody does .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Going to her .That 's just it . Be somebody ! Do n't do the easy , weak thing . Be strong ; be an example to other women . Heaven knows it 's time they had one !

div.stage: MRS. HUNTER enters Right . BLANCHE meets her .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Good morning , my poor dear .

div.stage: Going to kiss BLANCHE .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Taking MRS. HUNTER 'S hand and not kissing her .Good morning .

lg.l: Clara 's gone upstairs to see little Richard . Good morning ,
Ruth .

div.stage: She adds this with a manner of being on the defensive .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Dryly .Good morning .

lg.stage: Sitting by the table and looking at the picture papers .
lg.l: Is n't it awful ! What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I do n't know yet , mother .

lg.l: Do n't know ? Absolute divorce — no legal separation !
We 're staying at the Waldorf .

div.stage: BLANCHE sits discouragedly on the sofa .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Sitting beside her .I shall advise against , and do everything in my power to prevent , Blanche 's getting a divorce !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: You do n't mean to say you 'll carry those ridiculous notions of yours into practice ?— now that a scandal has come into our very family ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Oh , I know selfish , cynical , and worldly people wo n't agree with me , and I pity and sympathize with Blanche from the bottom of my heart .Taking and holding BLANCHE 'S hand .But I want her not to decide anything now ; wait till the first blows over , and then — well , then I feel sure she will do the strong , noble thing — the difficult thing — not the easy .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Withdraws her hand from RUTH 'S .No , you ask too much of me , Aunt Ruth ; I can n't do it .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I say do n't decide now — wait .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I do n't want to wait . I want to decide now and to cut my life free , entirely , from Dick 's .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: You used to agree with me . I 've heard you decry these snapshot , rapid-transit , tunnel divorces many a time . I 've heard you say when a woman has made her bed , she must lie in it — make the best of her bad bargain .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I always sympathized with a woman who sought a divorce in this state .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Oh , yes , but you can n't , can you ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No , but I 'm not strong enough to fight out an unhappy life for the sake of setting an example to other women — women who do n't want the example set !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Blanche , I counted on you to be strong , to be big —

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: With a voice full of emotion .But I love Ned Warden . He loves me — life stretches out long before us . Dick has disgraced us all . I do n't love him — should I give my happiness and Mr . Warden 's happiness for him ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Absurd ! We all have a right to happiness if we can get it . I have chosen ; let Blanche follow my example .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Disgusted .Yours ?Rises .Oh !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Following up the advantage .Yes , Blanche , do you want to follow your mother 's example ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No ! But the cases are not analogous !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Not what ? You need n't fling any innuendoes at Mr. Trotter ; it 's he who said it was my duty to stand by you , advise you , and all that sort of thing . I 'm not here to please myself ! Goodness knows , a divorce court is n't a very pleasant place to spend your honeymoon !

lg.l: Thank both you and Mr. Trotter , mother ; but I ask you to allow
Aunt Ruth and me to decide this matter between us .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Trotter says divorce was made for woman !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: And what was made for man , please ? Polygamy ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: I do n't know anything about politics ! But I could count a dozen women in a breath , all divorced , or trying to be , or ought to be !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: And each one of them getting a cold shoulder .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: What of it if their hearts are warm — poor climbers after happiness !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Believe me , dear , the chill spreads . You 're going to be selfish ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: She 's going to be sensible .

div.stage: CLARA enters Right .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Hello , everybody ! I just saw Dick coming out of his room and I cut him dead .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Clara !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: To BLANCHE .You 've taken a certain responsibility upon yourself , and you can n't shirk it .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: He is n't what I thought him !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: The day the sun shone on you as a bride , in God 's presence , you said you took him for better for worse —

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Dear me , is that in it ? The marriage service ought to be expurgated !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: To CLARA .I 'm ashamed of you .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: That 's nothing new !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Aunt Ruth , let us talk some other time .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Oh , if we are in the way , we 'll go !

div.stage: Rises .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Yes , come on , let 's go to Atlantic City .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: No , I 'd rather go to Lakewood .

lg.l: Oh , pshaw , Lakewood 's no fun ! I 'm surprised you do n't say go to
Aiken , North Carolina .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Mr. Trotter says we can n't leave town anyway while Blanche is in this trouble .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Mother , please discuss your affairs somewhere else .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: And if I may be permitted to suggest , you will find Mr. Trotter 's advice always pretty good to follow . That young man has better qualities than we have suspected . I have some thing to thank him for ; will you be good enough to ask him to come and see me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: He will not go to your house with my permission . I shall tell him you have never asked me inside your door .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Mother , if you ask me —MRS. HUNTER interjects “ Which I do n't , ” but CLARA continues without paying any attention to the interruption .— I do n't think Mr. Trotter is going to cry himself to sleep for your permission about anything !

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: To BLANCHE .Good-by , my dear ; if you want me , let me know ; I 'll be glad to do anything I can . I 'm staying at the Waldorf .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: It 's full of people from Kansas and Wyoming Territory come to hear the Opera !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: A little western blood would n't hurt our New York life a bit !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Ah ! Got you there ! The west is the place where the divorces come from !

lg.l: What 's the matter with Providence ? I think
Rhode Island tips the scales pretty even for the east !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Please go , mother ; please leave me for a little while .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: Oh , very well , good-by !LEONARD enters Right with a Christmas parcel , which he places on the table Right .Dear me , have you had all these Christmas presents and not opened them ?

lg.l: It is only little Richard in this house who is celebrating
Christmas to-day .

sp.speaker: MRS. HUNTER
sp.p: It 's a terrible affair ; I only hope the newspapers wo n't get hold of it .To LEONARD .If any women come here asking for me who look like ladies , do n't let ‘ em in ! They ai n't my friends ; they 're reporters .

div.stage: LEONARD bows and goes out .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I 'm awfully sorry , Blanche , I honestly am ; but I think you 'll have only yourself to blame if you do n't strike out now and throw Dick over . Good-by !

div.stage: MRS. HUNTER and CLARA go out Right .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I wish they would n't advise me to do what I want to .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: But who do I harm by it ? Surely , it would n't be for his good to be brought up under the influence of his father !

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: If he saw you patiently bearing a cross for the sake of duty , can you imagine a stronger force for good on the boy 's character ? What an example you will set him ! What a chance for a mother !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: But my own life , my own happiness ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Ah , my dear , that 's just it ! The watchword of our age is self ! We are all for ourselves ; the twentieth century is to be a glorification of selfishness , the Era of Egotism ! Forget yourself , and what would you do ? The dignified thing . You would live quietly beside your husband if not with him . And your son would be worthy of such a mother !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: And I ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: You would be glad in the end .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Perhaps —

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Surely ! Blanche , for twenty years Mr. Mason and I have loved each other .BLANCHE is astonished . There is a pause .RUTH smiles while she speaks , though her voice breaks .You never guessed ! Ah , well , your father knew .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: But Mrs. Mason is hopelessly insane ; surely —

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: A principle is a principle ; I took my stand against divorce . What can you do for a principle if you do n't give up everything for it ? Nothing ! And that is what I mean . To-day I am not sorry — I am happy .

div.stage: There is another slight pause . RICHARD is heard upstairs singing a Christmas carol , “ Once in Royal David 's City , ” etc .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: With great emotion .But if it breaks my heart — if it breaks my heart ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Hearts do n't break from the pain that comes of doing right , but from the sorrow of doing wrong !Neither woman speaks for a minute ; in the silence RUTH hears RICHARD .What 's that ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Hearing now for the first time .Richard singing one of his carols .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: I 'd forgotten it was Christmas .

div.stage: LEONARD enters Left .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Doctor Steinhart is here to see Mr. Sterling . Where shall I show him , madame ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Here ; we 'll go —

div.stage: Rising .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Yes , madame .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: RUT
sp.p: Well ? What are you going to do ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I 'm thinking —

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: May I come with you , or shall I —

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No , come .

div.stage: The two women start to leave the room together Right , with their arms around each other . They meet STERLING , who enters ; he starts , they stop .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I beg your pardon , I did n't know you were here .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: We are going to my room ; I am sorry you are not well .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Oh , it 's nothing , thank you .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: If we can do anything , let us know .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Overwhelmed with shame , bows his head .Thank you .

div.stage: The women go out Right . At the same moment DR. STEINHART is shown in by LEONARD Left .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Good morning , Sterling .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Good morning , doctor ; sit down .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: No , thanks , I 'm very rushed this morning . What can I do for you ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I 've been drinking too much for some time ; I can n't eat — my nerves are all gone to pieces . I 've some — some business troubles , and I have n't slept for a week .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Is that all ! Brace up , help yourself a little , and we can soon make a man of you .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I 'm afraid it would take more than a doctor to do that .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Oh , come , we must get rid of melancholy . Come and drive with me to 79th Street .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No , I 'm too worn out . Look at my hand !Holds out a trembling hand .I tell you literally I have n't slept for weeks — I thought you 'd give me some chloral or something .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: What ? Now ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Yes ; I 've tried sulphonal and all that rot ; if does n't have any effect on me . Give me a hypodermic —

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Nonsense ! Come out into the air !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I 've been out .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Good ! Then try lying down again , and perhaps you 'll go to sleep now .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Very well , but give me something to take to-night in case I can n't sleep then .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Takes out a note-book and writes with a stylographic pen .Be careful what you eat to-day . How about this drinking — did your business trouble come after it began , or did the whiskey come after the business trouble ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: That 's it .

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Um —Giving STERLING the paper which he tears out of his note-book .Look here , I 've a busy day before me ; but I 'll look in to-morrow , and we 'll have a good talk .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Thank you . I say , what is this ?

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: It 's all right . Sulphate of morphia — one-quarter-grain tablets .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Is n't that very little ?

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Oh , no ; you try one , and repeat in an hour if it has n't done its work .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: But you 've only given me two tablets , and I tell you I 'm awfully hard to influence !

sp.speaker: DR. STEINHART
sp.p: Two 's enough ; we do n't give a lot of drugs to a man in a nervous condition like yours . Do n't let them wake you for luncheon if you 're asleep . Sleep 's best for you . Good-by — pleasant dreams .

div.stage: He goes out Left .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Reads off the prescription .“ Two one-quarter-grain tablets sulphate of morphia , Wm . B. Steinhart — ” And in ink ! Why did n't he write it with a lead-pencil ? How can I make it more ? Two — wait a minute ! Two !Taking out his own stylographic pen .What 's his ink ?Makes a mark with his pen on his cuff .Good ! the same ! Why not make it twelve ?Marking a one before the two .Just in case — I might as well be on the safe side !

div.stage: He rings an electric bell beside the mantel , and waves the paper in the air to dry it . BLANCHE enters Right .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I heard the doctor go . Is anything serious the matter ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: If it were my body only that had gone wrong , Blanche !

div.stage: LEONARD enters Left .
To LEONARD . ] Take this prescription round the corner and have it put up .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Yes , sir .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: And bring it to me with a glass of water .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: He goes out Left .
BLANCHE is still standing . STERLING sinks into a chair , and puts his head in his hands , his elbows on the table . He lifts his head and looks at her .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I know what you 're going to do ; you do n't have to tell me ; of course you 're going to divorce me .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: What !

div.stage: His hands drop to the table ; he looks her straight in the face , doubting what he hears .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Looking back into his eyes .No .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Cries .Blanche !

div.stage: In a tone of amazement and joy .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I give you one more chance , for your sake only as my boy 's father . But — do n't make it impossible for me — do you understand ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Yes ! I must take the true advantage of this chance your goodness gives me . I must right myself , so that people need not hesitate to speak of his father in Richard 's presence . And this I will do .With great conviction he rises .I know I am at the cross-roads , and I know the way ; but I do n't choose it for your reasons ; I choose for my own reason — which is that , unfit as I am , I love you .

div.stage: He speaks deliberately and with real feeling , bending over her .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I tell you truly my love for you is gone for good .

lg.l: I 'll win it back — you did love me , you did , did n't you ,
Blanche ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I loved the man I thought you were . Do you remember that day in the mountains when we first really came to know each other , when we walked many , many miles without dreaming of being tired ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: And found ourselves at sunset at the top instead of below , by our hotel ! Oh , yes , I remember ! The world changed for me that day .

div.stage: He sinks back into the arm-chair , overcome , in his weakened state , by his memories and his realization of what he has made of the present .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: And for me ! I knew then for the first time you loved me , and that I loved you . Oh ! how short life of a sudden seemed ! Not half long enough for the happiness it held for me !She turns upon him with a vivid change of feeling .Has it turned out so ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: How different ! Oh , what a beast ! what a fool !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Speaking with pathetic emotion , tears in her throat and in her eyes .And that early summer 's day you asked me to be your wife !She gives a little exclamation , half a sob , half a laugh .It was in the corner of the garden ; I can smell the lilacs now ! And the raindrops fell from the branches as my happy tears did on father 's shoulder that night , when I said , “ Father , he will make me the happiest woman in the world ! ”

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: O God ! to have your love back !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: You can n't breathe life back into a dead thing ; how different the world would be if one could !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: You can bring back life to the drowned ; perhaps your love is only drowned in the sorrow I 've caused .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Smiles sadly and shakes her head ; the smile dies away .Life to me then was like a glorious staircase , and I mounted happy step after step led by your hand till everything seemed to culminate on the day of our wedding . You men do n't , can n't realize , what that service means to a girl . In those few moments she parts from all that have cherished her , made her life , and gives her whole self , her love , her body , and even her soul sometimes — for love often overwhelms us women — to the man who , she believes , wants , starves , for her gifts . All that a woman who marries for love feels at the altar I tell you a man can n't understand ! You treated this gift of mine , Dick , like a child does a Santa Claus plaything — for a while you were never happy away from it , then you grew accustomed to it , then you broke it , and now you have even lost the broken pieces !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Comes to her , growing more and more determined .I will find them , and put them together again .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Again smiles sadly and shakes her head .First we made of every Tuesday a festival — our wedding anniversary . After a while we kept the twenty-eighth of every month ! The second year you were satisfied with the twenty-eighth of April only , and last year you forgot the day altogether . And yet what a happy first year it was !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Ah , you see I did make you happy once !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Blessedly happy ! Our long silences in those days were not broken by an oath and a fling out of the room . Oh , the happiness it means to a wife to see it is hard for her husband to leave her in the morning , and to be taken so quickly — even roughly — into his arms at night that she knows he has been longing to come back to her . Nothing grew tame that first year . And at its end I climbed to the highest step I had reached yet , when you leaned over my bed and cried big man 's tears , the first I 'd ever seen you cry , and kissed me first , and then little Richard lying on my warm arm , and said , “ God bless you , little mother . ”There is a pause . BLANCHE cries softly a moment . STERLING is silent , ashamed . Again she turns upon him , rousing herself , but with a voice broken with emotion .And what a bad father you 've been to that boy !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I did n't mean to ! That 's done , that 's past , but Richard 's my boy . I 'll make him proud of me , somehow ! I 'll win your love back — you 'll see !

div.stage: BLANCHE is about to speak in remonstrance , but stops because of the entrance of LEONARD . He brings a small chemist 's box of tablets in an envelope and a glass of water on a small silver tray .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Your medicine , sir .

div.stage: He puts it on the table and goes out Right .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Thank you , thank you !

div.stage: He takes the box of tablets out of the envelope .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Going to him .You do n't realize why I 've told you all this !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Counting out the tablets .One , two . To give me hope ! To give me hope !

div.stage: He empties the other ten tablets into the envelope , twists it up , and throws it in the fireplace .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: No , no , just the opposite !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Then you 've defeated your end , dear ; you will stay here with me .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Trying to make him realize the exact position .Opposite you at the table , receiving our friends , keeping up appearances , yes — but nearer to you than that ? No ! Never !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: But you will stay ?

div.stage: LEONARD enters from Left .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Miss Godesby , Mr . Warden .

div.stage: They enter .
All greet each other . WARDEN nods stiffly to STERLING , barely acknowledging his greeting .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: To STERLING , purposely speaking with good-humored raillery to relieve the tension of the situation .Well , you 're a nice lot , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I 'm so ashamed ! I 'm so ashamed !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh , never mind that now .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: I have no words to thank you with .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Oh , that 's all right . The truth is , I 've made Warden bring me here , Sterling , for a bit of business . I had an emotional moment yesterday and went off my head a bit . I stand by what I said as to keeping quiet , but — well , I 'm like any other old maid who hates dust on her mantelpiece — I 'm fidgety not to make some sort of a bluff at putting this thing on a business basis .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Excuse me , Miss Godesby , I think Sterling ought to know the truth .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Now what ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Well , the truth is , my fool of a brother has kicked up an infernal row , and refuses to hold his tongue .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Then I 'm ruined after all !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Wait , I 've left him with Mr. Mason . I feel certain I can assure his silence if I can only show him some sort of an agreement to pay , an acknowledgment of the — the — affair , signed and sealed .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Signed by whom ?

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Your husband and yourself will do .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: But both names are worthless .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Not as a point of honor .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Ah ! no , not my wife 's .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Nor yours to me . Come along !

div.stage: She goes to the table with STERLING , and unfolding a paper gives it to him . He signs it .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Aside to BLANCHE , apologizing for his presence .She made me come — she would n't come alone ; otherwise I should have waited till you sent for me .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: It 's as well — I 've decided . Oh , I wonder if I 'm doing wrong .

div.stage: Looking him straight in the face .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Looking back searchingly in hers to read the truth , but believing that she will certainly leave her husband .No , you can n't do wrong ! But I must warn you of one thing — I 'm not any longer the controlled man I was .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Come along now , Mrs. Sterling , brace up and give me your name , and Warden , witness , please .They do so .Of course , my dears , I know perfectly well that legally this is n't worth the paper it 's written on .Exchanging a serious and meaning look with WARDEN .But my idiot of a brother wo n't realize that , which is the point . One thing more — will you both dine with me next week , Thursday ?There is an embarrassed pause , which , with quick intuition , she understands .Yes , you will — for silence gives consent !Laughing .Now , that 's settled !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: What an awfully good sort you are !

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Thanks , not always — I 've been a mucker more than once in my life ! I must goShaking hands with BLANCHE .and relieve Mr. Mason of my brother , or he 'll be accusing me of inhuman treatment ; more than one consecutive hour of my brother ought to be prevented by the police .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: You are very , very good .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: I think if you and I can get well over this , we 'll be real friends , and I have n't many , have you ?

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Takes her hand .You can count upon me and my boy so long as we live .

div.stage: She impulsively but tenderly kisses her .
MISS GODESBY is very much surprised , but moved .

sp.speaker: MISS GODESBY
sp.p: Half laughing , half crying , and pulling her veil down to hide her emotion .By George ! I have n't been kissed by a woman for years ! Good-by .

div.stage: WARDEN starts to go out with MISS GODESBY . BLANCHE stops him .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Wait one moment — I want to speak alone to Miss Godesby .

div.stage: MISS GODESBY goes out Left .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Aside to STERLING .You tell him ; I cannot . Tell him the truth .

div.stage: She goes out after MISS GODESBY .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Dick .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Ned ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: I have nothing to say to you , Sterling .

div.stage: WARDEN looks away and whistles a tune to show his unwillingness to listen . STERLING speaks clearly so WARDEN shall hear .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I have a message for you from my wife .There is a second 's pause . WARDEN stops whistling and turns and looks at STERLING .She asks me to explain — to tell — to tell you a decision she has come to .

div.stage: There is another pause .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Yes ?

div.stage: Anxious , at a supreme tension , and now a little alarmed as to the decision .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: She has decided not to leave my house .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Adds .Yet !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Ever !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Losing his control .That 's a lie !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I could n't believe it , either , when she told me . It was her first word to me to-day . I said , “ You are going to divorce me , ” and she answered , “ No . ”

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: She 's sacrificing herself for some reason — her boy !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Never mind , she wo n't leave me ; I have her promise , and I 'll win back her love !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: You fool ! You can n't win her back ! She would never have loved me if you had n't disillusioned , dishonored her ! I 'm not worthy of her , but I 'll never dishonor her , and , please God , never disappoint her , and so I 'll keep her love .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Well , as to that , she decides to stay , leaving love out of the question .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: And you 'll accept that sacrifice ! You do n't even love her . You 're only thinking of yourself now . Love , real love , forgets itself . You , after having spoilt half her life , are willing to spoil the rest , for your own sake !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No , for the boy 's sake , and her sake — to save a scandal — the world —

div.stage: Interrupted .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Beside himself .Oh , damn the world ! It 's heaven and hell you 'd better think of . Scandal ! It could n't harm her , and the hurt it would do you is a small price to pay . Those whom God has joined — yes ! but it was the devil bound her to you !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Here ! I 've had enough ! Look out !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Moves toward him .You look out — you sha n't rob her of her happiness . You — a drunkard ! A forger ! A thief !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I 'd keep her now if only to spite you !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Hah ! There spoke the true man in you ! Would to heaven the old days of duelling were back !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: A brave wish , as you know they 're not !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: They fight in other countries still for their love and honor , and I 'm ready here , now , if you are , with any weapons you choose !STERLING sneers .Sneer ! But will you fight ? We 'll find a place , and something to fight with , or fists if you 'd rather ! You would n't kill me before I 'd got you out of her way for good . Will you fight ?

div.stage: Coming closer to him .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Getting more and more enraged .If you lose , you go away , and set her free of your own will !

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Losing entirely his self-control .What do you want to make you fight — will that ?

div.stage: He gives him a stinging blow in the face .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Yes !

div.stage: He springs toward WARDEN as RUTH and MASON enter Left . The two men stand rigid , WARDEN breathing heavily .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Blanche , may I bring in — where 's Blanche ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Good morning , gentlemen .

div.stage: There is no response . WARDEN is with great difficulty restraining himself . His lips are compressed lightly and his hands clenched .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: What 's the trouble ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I have just told Warden my wife 's decision not to leave me .

lg.stage: Showing her relief and satisfaction in her face , turns to WARDEN .
lg.l: You wo n't try to shake that resolve ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Unable to control himself .But I will ! I will — I tell you all ! I hardly know what I say or do ! But look out for me , I 'm desperate ! I 'm a torrent that 's only let loose since yesterday , and now all of a sudden you try to stop me ! But it 's too late ; I 've got my impetus ; the repressed passion of years is behind me ; nothing can stop me — and God keep me from doing the wrong thing ! I am determined to clear him out of the way of the happiness of the woman I love .To RUTH .Do you mean to say you approve of her decision ?RUTH turns her head ; he turns to MASON .Do you ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: No .

lg.stage: To RUTH , holding out his hand .
lg.l: You will stand by me ,
Aunt Ruth , and together we —

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Interrupting and refusing his hand .Oh , no .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Do n't you think I can win her love back ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Wo n't you help me try ?

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: No . It would be useless .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Come with me to Blanche ; I must speak with her .

div.stage: WARDEN and RUTH go out Right .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Alone with STERLING .Go away and make your wife understand you are never coming back .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: But the loneliness , the misery , away — alone .

lg.l: Kill them with hard work ; you have other heavy debts , you know .
I came to see you about this business of your acknowledgments to Miss
Godesby and Miss Hunter .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Later , later . To-morrow I will decide —

div.stage: He motions him away . MASON goes to him and puts his hand on his shoulder .

sp.speaker: MASON
sp.p: Decide well —

div.stage: He hesitates a moment and then goes out Right .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Watching him go .There 's not one soul in this world who cares for me , and it 's my own fault .RICHARD is heard upstairs again singing “ Once in Royal David 's City . ” STERLING lifts his head and listens .Yes , one little soul loves me , and it would be better for him , too , if I went away . I 'll go to sleep and see how I feel about it when I wake up .He moves the glass of water and takes out the box of tablets . He starts suddenly , but very slightly , and his muscles tighten .After all , why not end it all now , at once , without any more bother ?He looks in the box , and glances up questioningly ; then he remembers the fireplace where he threw the other tablets and looks across the room at the logs . He rises , goes over , and sees in the fireplace the twisted envelope which holds the other tablets . He bends over to pick it up ; he stops short .No ! Why should n't I try it , anyway ? She , herself , gives me the chance !He rings the electric bell , and walking away from the fireplace , takes up with a trembling hand the papers left by MASON ; he wipes the damp from his forehead with his handkerchief . To JORDAN , who enters Left .Light the fire quickly ; I feel cold .

div.stage: He sinks into the arm-chair , weak from the mental strain .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: It 's very warm in the house , sir .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Do as I tell you — light the fire .

lg.stage: Looking for matches on the mantel , finds the box empty .
lg.l: There are no matches , sir ; I must get one .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No , do n't go — here — here —

div.stage: He gives him a match from his own box . LEONARD notices the trembling hand and suppressed excitement of STERLING , and involuntarily glances up , but quickly looks back to his work and strikes a match . The match goes out .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: I shall need another match , please , sir .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: With one in his fingers taken from his match-box , he alters his mind .I have no more .He puts away his match-box .Never mind the fire ; get me a pint bottle of champagne .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: With a surreptitious side glance of curiosity .Very well , sir .

div.stage: He goes out Left .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: That was funny ; that was very funny ! I wonder if it was accident , or if there 's such a thing as fatality .He goes to the fireplace and picks up the twisted envelope .If not now — perhaps some other time — who knows ?He thrusts the envelope in his vest pocket , and takes up the papers again from the table to look over them .I can n't read these things !Throwing them down .The words mean nothing to me !

div.stage: There is the sound outside of a cork being drawn . LEONARD enters with the champagne and a glass and places them beside STERLING .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Shall I light the fire now , sir ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No , never mind now .

sp.speaker: LEONARD
sp.p: Yes , sir .

div.stage: He goes out Left .
STERLING half fills the glass with champagne . He takes out the box of tablets and counts aloud .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: One , two , three , four —He puts all in the glass , dropping them as he counts . He hesitates , then quickly drops in two more and drinks quickly . The glass is empty . He sits by the table thinking a moment , then lakes a piece of paper and makes ready his stylographic pen .Let me see ; can I make it seem accidental ; it would be so much less bother and trouble for them !He thinks a second , then writes .“ I have accidentally taken an overdose of my sleeping draught . I have tried to call some one , but it 's no use . I ask only one thing , that you forget all my sins , wipe out their memory with my name . I want my boy to change his name , too . ”He hesitates a moment , and then scratches that sentence heavily out .No , I wo n't say that .He waits a moment .God in heaven , what would n't I give for one friendly word just now ! Some one to sort of say good-by to me — take my hand — even a servant !

div.stage: He looks about him , showing signs of drowsiness . The door Right bursts open . STERLING quickly hides the letter in his inside pocket as WARDEN comes in .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: My hat ! Where 's my hat !

div.stage: He looks about for it .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Quietly .Ned ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: My hat , I say ! Where 's my hat ?

div.stage: Looking .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Ned !

div.stage: Something in his voice arrests WARDEN 'S attention .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: What ?He looks at him .What 's the matter —

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Nothing — I 'm half asleep , that 's all — the reaction — I 'm worn out and I 've changed my mind —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: How do you mean ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I 'm going away for good — that 's the best I can do ; I want you to forgive me — could you ? What do you say ? Forgive me for everything ! For the sake of the old schoolboy days —

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: When are you going ?

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: To-day . Will you say good-by to me and wish me well on my journey ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Speaks without sympathy .You can count on me always to help you in any way I can . You can still retrieve a good deal if you 're strong enough .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: I know what a beastly friend I 've been , and yesterday was more than any man would stand , but forgive that , too , will you ? I 've always been a bad lot !

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Goes to him and speaks , with the sympathy of a man for a child coming into his voice .No , a weak lot ; that 's been your ruin , Dickie . I 'll see you again before you go .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: No , I 'm going to sleep as long as I can now , and I do n't want any one to wake me up ; but when I do wake , I shall have other things to do . This is good-by .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Well , good luck !He starts to go . The two men look at each other , and finally STERLING gets the courage to hold out his hand . WARDEN hesitates a moment , then shakes it .Good luck !

div.stage: He goes out Left .

STERLING , who has been growing more and more drowsy , as soon as he is alone , goes with difficulty to the door and locks it . He is so drowsy that he leans against the door for a moment ; then he starts to go back to the table , but is unable to get there and sinks on the sofa half way between the table and the door . His eyes close , but suddenly he starts violently and tries to rise , but cannot , crying out faintly .

sp.speaker: STERLING
sp.p: Good God — the money ! I forgot the money — who 'll pay my debts ? Ah , this is a fitting climax for my life — the weakest , dirtiest thing I 've done —He gets the letter from his pocket and holds it in his hand ; the light of the afternoon grows slowly dim , like his fading sight and senses . He murmurs twice in a faint , drowsy voice .Coward ! Coward !

div.stage: BLANCHE , in the hall outside Right , calls his name .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Dick !

div.stage: STERLING 'S body relaxes and sets . The letter drops from his lifeless hands .
BLANCHE enters with RUTH , followed by RICHARD , who rides a stick with a horse 's head and wears a soldier 's cap .

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.p: Merry Christmas , father !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Going toward the sofa .Dick !

sp.speaker: RICHARD
sp.p: Merry Christmas , father !

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Sh ! Father 's asleep .

div.stage: They steal back toward the other door when WARDEN enters Right .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Oh , you are here ! I went down into the drawing-room where I left you .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Sh !

div.stage: She points to STERLING , who lies apparently asleep . They speak in lowered voices .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Yes , I have a message for you from him .

div.stage: Looking at RICHARD and RUTH .

sp.speaker: RUTH
sp.p: Who understands .Come , Richard , I have n't seen your tree yet .

div.stage: She goes out Right with RICHARD .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: To BLANCHE .Give me your hand .

div.stage: She does so wonderingly .

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: Softly , with a man 's tenderness in his voice .He is going away for good .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Away ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: For good .

sp.speaker: BLANCHE
sp.p: Slowly , withdrawing her hand .For good ?She looks over toward STERLING , and then back to WARDEN .What does he mean ?

sp.speaker: WARDEN
sp.p: We will know when he wakes . THE CURTAIN STEALS SOFTLY DOWN
